26545466.review:
This review is written for Hexcells, Hexcells Plus, and Hexcells Infinite
[h1]Hexagonal Puzzler[/h1]
[b]Reviewed after completing all achievements[/b]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Hexcells plays like an average 2d puzzle games, you click your mouse to solve the puzzles not hard.  Untill you get to the later puzzles that is.  This game has one of the most ingenious puzzle systems I've played to date.  It isn't so complex that you're left scratching your head at what the rules that these puzzles follow are, but it isn't so simple that it becomes boring after you've completied a few of them.

I will say that while trying to %100 this game I looked up a few of the solutions [i]after[/i] completing them once.  This is because this game has a 'perfect' rating, in which there must be no missclicks on a puzzle to actually complete it for the achievements.  And while I did mess up sometimes when solving these puzzles, most of the time these missclicks were due to me acidentally resting my fingers on my buttons while trying to solve a hard section, or right clicking when I should have left clicked that time damn it!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

This game has a great look to it, but playing it at night will strain your eyes due to the brightness of it.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

This is a great game and well worth your time if you're looking for a puzzle game to play.  Though the achievement in Hexcells Infinite where you must complete some of the random puzzles just takes far too long.

[h1] 8/10 [/h1]

26298915.review:
Sehr schönes Rätselspiel für zwischendurch! :) Es erinnert im Grunde stark an das klassische Minesweeper. 

[h1]Spielprinzip:[/h1]
Ziel des Spiels ist es, alle Felder aufzudecken. Dabei helfen Zahlen in den Sechsecken (Hexagons) sowie über den Spalten. Die Felder können jedoch auf 2 verschiedene Arten aufgedeckt werden: Entweder blau, oder schwarz. 
Die schwarzen Felder geben dabei Hinweise darauf, wieviele blaue sich um sie herum befinden. 
Ein kleines Beispiel: In einem der aufgedeckten schwarzen Sechsecke findet sich die Zahl 4, d.h. es müssen um dieses Feld herum 4 blaue Felder aufgedeckt werden. Der Rest wird schwarz markiert. Dadurch ergeben sich wiederrum neue Möglichkeiten das Spielfeld zu lösen. Im Laufe des Spiels erhält der Spieler weitere Hinweise dazu, die den Schwierigkeitsgrad etwas steigern. Fehler beim Aufdecken des Spielfeldes werden im Gegensatz zu Minesweeper allerdings verziehen. Lediglich eine kleine Anzeige gibt Preis, dass ein Fehler gemacht wurde.

[h1]Grafik & Soundtrack:[/h1]
Grafisch ist das Spiel sehr einfach, aber dennoch ansehnlich gestaltet. Der Soundtrack ist ebenfalls sehr entspannend. 

[h1]Spielumfang und Schwierigkeitsgrad:[/h1]
Da Hexcells [b]keine zufallsgenerierten Level[/b] enthält, ist nach [b]ca. 1-2 Stunden[/b] das Spiel durchgespielt.
Dabei stehen dem Spieler [b]6 Welten mit insgesamt 30 Leveln[/b] zur Verfügung, wobei einige von ihnen eher einem Tutorial entsprechen. Den Schwierigkeitsgrad würde ich auf "Mittel" einschätzen.

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Ein sehr schönes Spiel, dass altbekannte Spielprinzipien erfrischend zusammenbringt. Daher für Rätselliebhaber zu empfehlen. 
Lediglich die festen Level mindern den Wiederspielwert... Der [b]Nachfolger Hexcells Infinite[/b] hat es da deutlich besser gemacht: Ein [b]Zufallsgenerator[/b] bietet Unmengen an Levels zusätzlich zur altbekannten "Kampagne" :)

26288325.review:
Hexcells est un puzzle game qui reprend les bases du démineur et les applique en utilisant des hexagones au lieu des carrés (avec 6 voisins au lieu de 8 donc), ce qui lui donne donc une base plus simple. Cependant il y ajoute progressivement des règles additionelles sur le nombre d'hexagones à révéler sur une ligne donnée, ou dans un périmètre donné, ou avec des règles supplémentaires qui ajoutent des conditions en plus (du type tous les hexagones à révéler doivent se toucher, ou doivent être séparés selon une combinaison bien précise), on est là face à du petit jeu (à petit prix). Le jeu est le premier d'une série et il introduit le concept, en conséquence les débuts sont extrêmement simples et ressemblent à un long tutorial, et il faut attendre la fin du jeu pour avoir quelques puzzles vraiment difficiles. 
 
En parlant de difficulté, pour bien jouer à Hexcells, il faut savoir que tous les puzzles ont une solution purement logique disponible (i.e qui permet de tout révéler à coup sur, sans devoir tenter sa chance ou quoi que ce soit), et en conséquence le jeu est bien plus agréable s'il est abordé dans cette optique. S'il est certes possible de deviner des pièces de temps en temps, ou de tenter sa chance, l'ajout de ces quelques hexagones révélés "supplémentaires" rend assez souvent triviale la résolution du reste du problème car ils vous donnent des données que vous n'étiez pas censé avoir, ce qui vous conduira à terminer le jeu en un temps très court et sans satisfaction, un peu de self contrôle sera donc nécessaire pour profiter des puzzles !

25996827.review:
[h1]Hexcells
3/10[/h1]
[b]Ciekawy saper?[/b]

Największym mankamentem gry są moim zdaniem nieprecyzyjne wskazówki służące do rozwiązywania plansz. Nie wiadomo na przykład, czy wskazówka {3} przy kolumnie oznacza, że w kolumnie są 3 sąsiadujące pola, bez względu na przerwy w kolumnie, czy uwzględniając te przerwy.

Drugi poważny minus - beznadziejne menu, które nie zawiera informacji o postępach na planszach, które rozwiązaliśmy. Za każdą rozwiązaną planszę dostajemy sumę punktów, która zmniejsza się wraz z błędami popełnionymi podczas jej rozwiązywania. By przejść do następnej grupy plansz musimy osiągnąć określoną sumę z wszystkich poprzednich. Po rozwiązaniu plansz z 5 grup nie starczyło mi punktów, by odblokować ostatnią 6 grupę. Nie wiedząc ile punktów zostało do zdobycia na poprzednich planszach musiałem przechodzić grę od początku, tym razem rozwiązując wszystkie plansze bezbłędnie. Co za durnota.

Z powodu pierwszego błędu nie ukończyłem ostatniej 6 grupy. Po prostu nie chciało mi się dochodzić do tego, co autor miał na myśli. Skoro od początku gry podawał wszystkie informacje, dlaczego nie wyjaśnił wszystkich zasad i pominął te najtrudniejsze do sprawdzenia doświadczalnie. Poziom trudności - od banału do średniego, przy większych planszach trzeba się trochę zastanowić.

Oprawa graficzna i muzyczna są na przyzwoitym poziomie, nic nie zachwyca. Grafika jest prosta i czytelna, dobrze, że autor nie dodawał jakiegoś tła na siłę, choć mam pewną wizję, by grafika w tej grze naprawdę zachwycała, a gra pozostała prosta i czytelna. Ambientowa muzyka nie nuży za bardzo, a sample odgrywane podczas wykonywania akcji miło jej dopełniają.

Miałem przy tej grze trochę zabawy, ale więcej było frustracji z powodu nieogarnięcia przez twórców pierwszej w/w sprawy, która spowodowała, że gra nie jest 'easy to learn and difficult to master' a przeciwnością tej cechy.

25995439.review:
Il vostro PC è un tostapane?
Avete speso tante di quelle ore su Campo Minato, Sudoku e simili al punto tale che avreste potuto laurearvi, trovare un lavoro e sposarvi?
Se la risposta è Sì, allora questo è il gioco che fa per voi.

Hexcells è un puzzle game molto interessante ispirato a Campo Minato con qualche richiamo a Sudoku. In ogni livello dovrete sbloccare tutti gli esagoni, e per farlo il gioco vi fornisce indizi come per esempio quante celle blu si trovano in una colonna o sono adiacenti a un esagono nero, ecc.
Man mano che si procede la complessità dei livelli aumenta sempre più, ma comunque, il gioco non è un gioco basato sulla fortuna: niente è lasciato al caso. Gli indizi che vi forniscono sono strutturati in maniera tale che potete finirlo senza fare un errore (sfida che gli amanti hardcore dei puzzle apprezzeranno).
Graficamente si presenta minimalista e piacevole, in grado di girare anche su PC estremamente datati.

L'unico difetto è l'assenza di un generatore di livelli e la possibilità di poter salvare la partita anche durante un livello. Per la seconda spesso ovviavo a ciò facendo uno screenshot del livello.

Hexcells Plus aggiunge sostanzialmente altri livelli, più complessi presentando gli stessi difetti del primo.
Hexcells Infinite, invece, oltre ad aggiungere nuovi livelli risolve anche i difetti legati ai primi due giochi, ovvero la generazione casuale di livelli e la possibilità di salvare la partita.
Sono giochi che consiglierei l'acquisto in bundle (Hexcells Complete Pack) e magari a prezzo scontato.

25981371.review:
This is one of those games that make me regret the fact that Valve only allows a positive or a negative opinion, and not a neutral one.

This game is admittedly brilliant. An extremely addictive combination of Minesweeper and Picross, with pretty visuals and a nice ambient soundtrack that reacts to your moves. I loved every minute of playing this game. Why the negative review then? Because it's really effing short. There are 36 puzzles, but they are easy enough that you can finish the game (and I don't mean "finish" as in "reach the last puzzle". I mean "finish" as in "beat all puzzles perfectly and get 100% of the achievements") fast enough to refund it, and the replay value is nonexistent. It feels like a demo/tutorial for the later Hexcells games.

Overall, I'd recommend to only buy it if the Hexcells Complete Bundle is on sale. It'll teach you how to play the later games with a much gentler learning curve. On it's own, and at the full price, this game is simply not worth it.

25979288.review:
Hexcells is a game about logic puzzels much in the vein of Minesweeper. Thankfully it gradually introduces more interesting game mechanics. But sadly it never goes beyond the tutorial stage and it isn't as upfront about teaching you the specifics of each mechanic as I'd like it to be. As a seasoned player of Minesweeper and logic puzzels in general it took me less than 2 hours to complete this game without ever making a single mistake. There is little replayability.

The design is clean and appealing (if a little bright), the sounds are neat and create an interesting atmosphere. I've never encountered a bug, error or crash.

If you pick this game up as part of the trilogy compilation it is a decent introducton to the series and you won't regret your purchase as the later parts offer much more gameplay and are well worth their money. I cannot recommend picking up the first part as a stand-alone and definitely not at full price.

25962904.review:
六边形的豪华版扫雷，习惯了正方形扫雷的可以来玩玩这个，意外的好玩呢。

关卡有点少，不过好在此游戏有两个续作。玩法不用介绍，点开六边形数字是其周围六个格子内蓝色方块的个数，但猫某习惯的叫它“炸弹”。游戏的亮点在于蓝色方块布局的提示与纵横总蓝色方块的布局方式和数量，这里照顾英语不是很出色的朋友，简单说下数字的符号代表什么。首先是不代任何符号的数字，与经典扫雷一样，只提示了周围以及一列的蓝色方块数量而已；带“{}”符号的，表示周围或者一列的蓝色方块都是紧挨着的；带“--”符号的，表示周围或者一列中至少有两个蓝色方块不挨着。然后，根据古典概率问题来推断蓝色方块所在位置，化随机为绝对，最终通关。

键位修改：默认是左键开蓝色方块，右键开空地，习惯玩扫雷的玩家都是右键插flag的，所以最好把鼠标左右键映射对调一下。

全成就：很简单，通了关就可以全成就了。但注意，解锁每大关都需要收集奖励方块的，所以尽量别失误哦。

25961467.review:
Enjoyed this game a lot! Gives a minesweeper kind of feel, which adds in more puzzle enhancements as you progress through the levels. Starts off very basic so that you get a feel for the game, and then you look up and all you want to do is perfect all the levels. So the games goes, there are a few blocks with numbers on the board and you have to puzzle out whether the block is another number or a blue block. The block has 6 sides (obviously) and the number says how many blue block are touching it. As the game progresses, it adds {} around a number to say the blue blocks are sequential, or -- around a number to say they are split. It then goes father to say that there are so may in this line by putting the number on the outside of that row or column. The easy feature which helps a lot for bigger puzzles is that you can click on the outside number and it draws a line through that row or column to see which ones.

All in all lots of fun and challenging at the same time. Can wait to play the rest of the games to see what new puzzling features arise!

25960836.review: Minesweaper minus RNG. Basically perfect as a puzzle game. It took me 1:50, but mine says more because I left it open.

25959924.review:
이번 할인에 패키지로 구매한 게임입니다.
은근히 머리를 많이 써야 하더군요. 머리를 쓰는 걸 좋아하시는 분들께 추천해요.
게임의 전체적인 느낌은 지뢰찾기와 비슷합니다. 정해진 규칙에 따라 셀을 확실한 것부터 하나하나 두 가지 종류로 구분해, 모든 셀을 밝혀내는 것이 게임의 목표입니다.

스테이지가 내용이 변하지 않고 고정되어 있어서 실수했던 스테이지를 재시도해 완벽하게 클리어하는 것이 가능해요.
만약 도전과제를 달성하는 것이 목표라면, 스테이지 클리어만 하면 되기에 머리가 좋지 않더라도 반복을 통해 얼마든지 달성할 수 있습니다. 정 안 되면 사진을 찍어놓든가 해서 말이죠.

전체적으로는 괜찮았지만 아쉬운 점을 꼽자면, 역시 부족한 볼륨이 되겠네요.
좋지 않은 제 머리로도 2시간 반만에 클리어했을 정도니까요. 특히 (한 월드당 5개 정도의 스테이지가 있는)총 6개의 월드 중에 4~ 5개의 월드가 [듀토리얼 -> 응용] 의 느낌이라 볼륨이 더 부족하게 느껴졌어요.
저야 묶음으로 플러스와 인피니트까지 구매했기에 상관없다지만, 단품으로 구매하시려는 분들이 이 글을 보신다면 한번쯤 고민해보셔야 할 것 같네요.

Весьма неплохая игра, созданная по типу всем известного Сапёра. Рекомендована для любителей головоломок и задачек, а так же для тех, кто хотел бы войти в круг таковых. Для любителей поломать мозги она будет просто хорошим отдыхом от сложных задач, а для новичков - тем, что не заставит навсегда позабыть про головоломки :) 
Минус игры - статичность уровней. Т.е. генерации уровней нет, существует только 30 определённых головоломок, которые при повторном прохождении уже будут неинтересны. Хотя может это кому-то будет плюсом - если не прошёл с первого раза всё идеально, то перезагрузив уровень можно быстро воссоздать нужную картинку. Так же можно отнести к минусам недостаток сложных уровней.
Плюсы игры:
 приятный саунд;
 легкая графика, которая не режет глаз;
 АЧИВКИ!!! Очень легко получить идеальную игру.
Оценка: 9 из 10.

25916391.review:
マインスイーパをハニカム構造にしたパズルゲーム。
というだけではなく、（マインスイーパでいうところの）地雷の連続性に関する情報や、列に存在する数といった情報が徐々に追加されていく。
最もマインスイーパと異なっている点は、完全情報ゲームであるということ。つまり「残り2マス、でも地雷は1個」みたいなことは絶対に無い。ギャンブルに頼ることになったら、それは頭が足りていないだけだ。

上記の点から、マインスイーパとは明らかに違うゲームであると分かろう。
既存のパズルゲームで何に一番似ているかといえば、数独あたりになると思う。

序盤の問題はかなり簡単で、セールで買ったくせに損をしたと思ってしまったが、前述した追加情報の要素が追加されていき難しくなるにつれて、その不満は無くなった。

最後に一点。
マインスイーパとはデフォルトの操作が左右のクリックで逆（左が「フラッグ」、右が「掘削」）である。
最初はデフォルト設定で始めたが、どうも慣れなくてスムーズに操作ができなかったため、結局入れ替えて操作している。

Recomendado si te viene en un Bundle o si eres un forofo de los puzzles de lógica. Por el precio estándar me parece muy caro para los pocos niveles que tiene. Como tantos puzzles lo veo más como un juego de móvil que en una biblioteca gamer de Steam.

Para entender la lógica del juego podemos decir que es un buscaminas avanzado. Está muy bien pensado y es muy adictivo. Lo que haces es descubir casillas decidiendo si tienen color o no. Cada vez que descubres una te muestra cuantas de color debe haber alrededor (de ahí que diga que es como el buscaminas). Luego se añaden una serie de señales adicionales que te pueden decir cuantas casillas de color hay en una hilera, si van continuadas o no, etc... 

El puzzle, como digo, está muy bien pensado y es bastante relajante. Ayuda mucho la musiquita New Age que le acompaña: perfecta para ambientar o para escuchar en el Spa mientras te dan un masaje.

25787793.review:
Hexcells is a fairly simple game, much of it employing a combination of mechanics from minesweeper and nonograms (Picross) on a non standard 2D grid. It is a logic game were rules of the levels are defined by numbered brackets (minesweeper style) that give information on whether nearby brackets are false or true. This is sometimes mixed in with column markers that do the same, but for a column (picross style). To deepen the gameplay a bit more, you are sometimes also presented with special rules beside the numbers which frankly, in my humble opinion, make minesweeper look like a joke. It feels like the kind of game you'd see in the crossword puzzle section in a digital newspaper of the future.

It's all good fun, really. Perfectly balanced, not hard nor easy. If any of these aforementioned games interest you, give this a try. For the low price point the developers are asking, you owe it to yourself to play this. Took me a good two and a half hours to get to 100%.

Good game for a buck; pushing it at $3.

25661290.review:
An enjoyable puzzle game, for about 2 hours, if you play quickly. Then you decide to perfect every level... You accidentally right-click instead of left-click and almost punch a hole through your monitor. Realizing that it is all your own fault, you try again. After making the same mistake four times, you decide that it might be smart to slow down for a few minutes and concentrate purely on which mouse-button to click.

I enjoyed the game until the penultimate level. That level is pure BS and you will not get a perfect on it the first, I almost guarantee it. It took me about 30 minutes to finally perfect that level, some accidental wrong-mouse-button-clicking may have taken place... but nonetheless an enjoyable experience overall. 

I would recommend this game for people who want to kill a couple of hours. It is a decent, somewhat repetitive puzzle-game. You either mark the hexagon, or clear it to see numbers underneath. Simple as that. I bought all three of the games (Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite) on sale. I expect the others to be similar to this one, with new features and quirks. I don't know if it is worth full-price, but for US$3 or whatever your currency may be, it is a decent purchase.

25659474.review: Hexcells and its sequels are absolutely essential to anyone that loves logic puzzle games like Picross and Sudoku. Contrary to the belief of the occasional negative (bad) reviewer, there is ALWAYS a logical way to proceed, without any guesswork. It often requires that you change the way you think about solving the puzzles, as following the same rules will only take you so far. Particularly, when it gets to the point that you have to start systematically eliminating cells as possible answers one at a time, or weighing your options based on the number of blue cells remaining, I can see why certain players would simply give up and call it impossible. It's not; I promise. Keep at it, or try to find a spoiler free hint to give you an idea of how to think through it rather than just giving you the answers.

Delightful little puzzle game that stretches your cortex just enough to make you work but never so tough to make your focus snap or resign yourself to guesswork.  The levels are a soothing palette (especially compared to Minesweeper!) and the gentle chiming ambient soundtrack is a perfect fit; highly recommended to anyone with a few hours to concentrate and try something different.  

Mac specific notes - a few quirks in the game were noted: screen size was wonky when pulling up the Steam overlay in game whether played windowed or not, and the music would disconnect randomly when I attempted to plug in or select headphones as a listening option under my System Preferences (on iMac).  Nothing that impeded actual gameplay, but somewhat irritating hiccups nonetheless.

And it took me a while to nail it down, but the music sounds wonderfully akin to FAX Records' early works!  That is just about the highest praise I can offer a game's soundtrack, btw.

25448351.review: Hexcells is a sublimely simple puzzle game. Yes, it is short, especially once you get a hang of the game's core mechanics, but there's fun to be had in completeting all of the game's puzzles and 100%-ing it. 25391959.review:
Puzzle games are easy to come by these days. Unfortunately, for every Tetris or Panel de Pon out there, sometimes you can get a puzzle game that feels like it's cheating you by not giving you all the hints you need to solve the puzzle or worse, requires you to guess your way through puzzles leaving them to sheer luck.

Hexcells is not that game.

It starts simple, as most puzzle games do with a number on a hexagon that tells you how many hexagons are directly adjacent to that one. From there, the game builds on its rules, adding layers of complexity at a nearly perfect pace. The puzzles in this game and its two sequels are truly fun and challenging to solve in a way that only the best puzzle games are, leading to what really makes the game special :

Hexcells makes YOU feel smart. 

You start to see patterns and infer more information than is just presented to you plainly on the screen. Your brain naturally takes over and starts to work within the rules provided in the game in a way that really makes you feel like you've accomplished something when you complete a puzzle with no mistakes. Every puzzle in this game can be solved through logic, no guesssing required.

Absolutely recommended as a great way to keep your mind in shape.

25290852.review:
This is one of those games that screams "why didn't I think of that?". At its core it may look like hexagonal minesweeper, but that is just the most visible aspect. You see, as a puzzle game, minesweeper has quite some randomness and, at times, guesswork. Hexcells manages to maintain and even improve the depth of that game while removing the randomness element. Every level is solvable, but at times, it introduces extra information about the columns or the adjacent blocks. But as you can guess, the trick to properly SOLVE the puzzle (meaning: reducing all guesses) is to combine the bits of data you have to come to clear knowledge on whether a block is a "bomb" (okay, "part of the pattern") or not.

I haven't played plus or infinite yet, but it's not hard to see why other reviewers treat these games and this one as a single game. It's because it is. And to be frank: the only reason the developer gets away with it is because even the single parts are easily worth the small asking price (3 bucks? You can just as well call these games stand-alone DLC). So even with this warning, this is a very easy thumbs up. :-)

25276352.review:
Hexcells is really a fantastic game and value for logic puzzle fans.  

The game is similar to Minesweeper with a few changes.  First, one mistake doesn't end the game, (and in fact a single mistake still gives "full" score.   

Second the grid is made out of hexagons rather than squares.  Instead of the eight neighboring blocks, there's the 6 neighboring grid squares. 

Third, there's a number of different solving techniques and clues.  Whether it be connected numbers, disconnected numbers, or just hints about rows. 

Finally the game is based on perfectly solvable grids, rather than random (and potentially unsolvable) puzzles.   The game contains 36 levels, and they range in difficulty, but they're all quite well done. 

There's two sequels that are more difficult, for someone who's looking for a real challenge, but as a introduction to the game, Hexcells does a fantastic job, and at a realistic price. 

(I would recommend all three games)

25260586.review:
[i]Miny… bez min.[/i]

Hráli jste někdy windowsí Minesweeper (“Hledání min”)? Zjistili jste, podobně jako já, že je to vlastně celkem zábávná hra? Pokud ano, mohly by vás zaujmout Hexcells.

Hexcells je logická hra založená na jednoduchém - “minovém” - principu. Každé políčko na hexovém hracím poli je buď “modré”, nebo je označeno číslem = počtem modrých polí na okolních hexech (Blbě se to popisuje, pusťte si Hledání min:-). Postupně odkrýváte hexy: Pokud si myslíte, že je pole modré tak levým myšítkem, pokud si myslíte že modré není, tak pravým. Snažíte se bez chyb odkrýt celé hrací pole (na rozdíl od Min nevybuchujete, chyby se vám nicméně počítají). Jednoduché… pokud vám není cizí troška systematičnosti, nebo jste hodně hráli...však víte co. 

Hexcells je ovšem hra celkem vyjímečná tím, že se autorovi povedlo rozšířením jednoduchých pravidel o další a trošku komplikovanější (víte kolik modrých je v linii, víte jestli spolu všechny sousedí, víte jestli spolu naopak nesousedí apod.) vytvořit ještě o něco zábavnější hru. Jednotlivá kola nejsou náhodně generovaná, jsou to puzzly, v nichž je vaším úkolem hledat to správné pravidlo, které můžete v daný moment použít. Vlastně se tak potkávají Miny a Sudoku - pokud jsou tyhle hry vaše krevní skupina, doporučuju Hexcells vaší pozornosti. 

Největší “ale” se ovšem skrývá ve velmi malém počtu těžkých kol. Přišlo mi, že většina hry se zabývá vysvětlováním pravidel a zajímavějších kol je pak méně než 10. Dohrál jsem všechno bez chyb za 3 hodiny (a nejvíc jsem bojoval s posaným ovládáním, které se přece jen liší od Min - uklikávál jsem se častěji než by bylo zdrávo; na druhou stranu hra nijak neměří čas, takže můžete hrát soustředěně a opatrně:-)

Za kolik stojí: 0,5€
S ostatními hrami v packu? Nevím, zatím jsem Hexcells Plus a Hexcells Infinite nezkoušel, nicméně základní hra mě na ně celkem navnadila...

25253702.review:
Hexcells se podría definir como un juego de puzzles minimalista evolución del buscaminas.

La mecánica del juego no puede ser más sencilla: encontrar todos los hexágonos azules del tablero, pero no te engañes, una mecánica sencilla no implica que el juego sea fácil, por lo que encontrarás que la dificultad se incrementa a cada nivel. Mediante clicks con el botón principal descubriremos las celdas azules en un tablero lleno de rectángulos amarillos y negros, que nos darán pistas de la cantidad de celdas azules que hay alrededor, haciendo que estrujemos nuestro cerebro para no equivocarnos.

El juego no es muy extenso, en un par de horas se puede completar, algo que podríamos considerar una contra a su compra a pesar de su bajo precio.

Recomiendo su compra si te gustan los juegos de puzzle y de lógica ya que te mantendrá enganchado hasta su finalización.

It's kind of similar to Minesweeper, BUT, while Minesweeper always requires some guessing, some trial and error, this game is 100% logical. There is a clear solution to every level which can be solved without guessing even once. In that sense, it's similar to Sudoku, but simpler.

Interesting puzzler. Finished in a single sitting of about an hour an a half, enjoyed every moment of it.

Not the hardest of puzzlers, but enjoyed it very much. It gently introduces new concepts to make the game more diffucult, and the puzzles grow larger as well. Where the first ones take several seconds, the last few can take up to ten minutes. Not having an undo button is logical, as mistakes are immediately made known, but when your fingers don't follow your brain (i.e. when you want to left-click and you right-click, or the other way around), this is frustrating, as you have to start the puzzle anew entirely to perfect it.

I would recommend to people who enjoy a quick challenge and puzzles in general. Otherwise, I'd steer clear of it - then again, why would you be looking at a puzzler review if you are not interested? ;)

25108478.review:
Hexcells is, on the most basic level, a more sophisticated version of Minesweeper. You are given a layout of golden hex tiles, possibly with one or more of them already highlighted or flipped. Flipped tiles have numbers on them, and also labels indicating whether or not adjacent tiles which should be highlighted are continuous or non-continuous (or no designator at all). There are also row and column labels which allow you to see how many tiles need to be highlighted in any given row or column.

Each puzzle mixes these up in a unique way to push you to solve it.

Thinking about this game as a more sophisticated version of minesweeper is, I think, fairly ideal, because that is more or less what it is, and the function it serves. It is something to throw away a bit of time on, not sit down and play continuously.

But even then, you’re not looking at it taking all that long to complete; the whole game takes less than two and a half hours to solve, and that’s assuming you’re trying to get a perfect score on every stage.

It is about as fun as Minesweeper is, and I’d basically consider it filling that role in your game library.

My advice? Pass. It isn’t a bad puzzle game, but it isn’t anything remarkable either. If you did get it as part of a bundle or something, it isn’t a terrible thing to install and just screw around with when you’d mess around with solitaire or minesweeper or whatever, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to buy this.

24730745.review:
A very short puzzle game which increases in difficulty the more levels you unlock and play. 

[b]Graphics: 10/10[/b]
It shows itself in a minimalistic way with almost only 5 colours present at the screen at the same time. With this, it achieves a simple yet deceiving look. 

[b]Storyline: 1/10[/b]
It has NONE at all. Just do the puzzles and finish the game. No story to be seen here.

[b]Sound: 10/10[/b]
The soundtrack is really ambient. You would hardly notice it due to the fact that you are concentrating so hard to complete the puzzle. But if you take the time to listen to it, it sounds very good, even for a £2 puzzle game. I am impressed by this. 

[b]Gameplay: 10/10[/b]
If you’ve played Minesweeper before, this uses the same concept, but it is a lot more forgiving and a lot more relaxing as it doesn’t put you in pressure. Other than that, it has a smooth gameplay with absolutely no lag whatsoever. 

[b]Price: 10/10[/b]
At only £1.99, this game is totally worth the price. It even comes in a bundle with 2 other games if you’re interested in getting those as well. (You save money if you get that). If not, you can wait until it goes on sale and get it for a VERY cheap price.

24723936.review:
[h1]THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | 2 *3*] = ~88% (75%-100%)[/h1]

I recommend that you buy the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/sub/50074/]Hexcells Complete Pack[/url] with all 3 games - that's why this review text is identical for all 3.

It's a [i]great[/i] puzzle game series that strongly reminds of Microsoft Minesweeper, but not only is the grid hexagonal (meaning 3 instead of 2 axes), the games even go well beyond mere neighbor-field estimation.

The levels eventually get very hard, and the procedural mode in "Hexcells Infinite" that exists in addition to the hand-crafted levels all three games have is a bit too chaotic (and hard) for my personal taste - well, it's procedural, its levels are not nicely designed and organized like the other levels.

Anyway, since I wanted [i]more[/i] of the easier puzzles and especially of the feature that numbers at the grid's periphery say something about the grid's content, I made a (very crappy) [url=http://dreamspace-president.com/index_crappyGames.html#StupidLittleMinesweeper]puzzler[/url] in a few hours after finishing the Hexcells games that helps a bit with those needs.

Hey, Matthew Brown, if you ever make a game like this again, I'm very likely to buy it, and I bet there's a bunch of people out there who think alike.

For those who like this kind of puzzle game, I can't recommend the Hexcells games enough.

24683810.review:
Minesweeper on hexes with more variety in the numbers for rules. Starts simple ("2 neighboring hexes should be lit up") and gets more complicated ("20 columns of hexes, with a few lit to start, and a particular number of hexes to light in half of the columns, then along some of the diagonals, and some of those are continuous and others cannot be continuous and..."). Good puzzle design. Only about an hour of play to get a perfect score on every level, but it is a worthwhile hour.

24635648.review:
[Play Time] : 약 2시간 내외 (스팀 도전과제 100% 진행 기준)

[게임장르] : 퍼즐게임

[게임소개]
: 육각형(헥셀)의 네모네모로직과 지뢰찾기를 맛깔나게 버무린 퓨전 형태의 퍼즐게임

[한줄 평]
: 저렴한 가격에 즐길 수 있는 흡입력 강한 퍼즐게임이나 후속작(Plus, Infinite)이 나온 시점에서는 Demo 게임과 비슷


[게임평가]
: 네모네모로직과 지뢰찾기를 맛깔나게 잘 버무린 퍼즐게임(Hexells) 입니다.

<아래 설명은 필자의 Hexcells Infinite 게임 평가란을 참조함 >
-------------------------------------------------------------
본 작품은 비록 한국어화가 되어 있지 않지만 친절한 튜토리얼로 게임 Rule에 대해 자세히 설명하고 있기에 게임을 학습하고 진행하는데 큰 어려움이 없습니다. 그리고 게임을 플레이 하게 되면 게임 초반 육각형(헥셀)에 숫자가 표기되어 있고 그 주위에 파란 헥셀의 갯수를 나타내는 것이 꼭 단순한 지뢰찾기의 업그레이드 버전이라고 생각할 수 있으나 '{}', '-' 등을 통해 파란색 헥셀의 위치를 다양하게 표기하고 있기에 단순한 지뢰찾기의 업그레이드 버전이라고 보기에는 어려울듯 싶습니다.

또한 상하좌우의 라인의 숫자 또한 '{}', '-' 옵션을 통해 파란색 헥셀이 위치를 다양하게 표현하고 있으므로 일반적인 네모네모로직에서도 좀 더 발전된 형태로 이 발전된 게임방식들이 잘 버무려져 흡입력 강한 헥셀이라는 퍼즐게임로 재탄생되었다는것은 필자의 조그마한 뻥(?)을 덧붙여 기존에 존재하는 것으로 부터 한단계 발전된 퍼즐로 퍼즐계의 한 획을 긋는 대단한 발견이 아닐까 싶습니다
-------------------------------------------------------------

그럼에도 불구하고 해당 게임에 대해 비추천 하는 이유는 Hexcells 이후 후속작 'Plus -> Infinite' 2개가 발매 되었기 때문입니다. 추가적인 설명을 드리자면 Hexcells 초기작품이 발매되었던 시기에 플레이 한 뒤 평가를 작성하였다면 비추천 없이 긍정적인 문구만 적혀 있었을 것이며, 평가란에도 극찬과 함께 매우 긍정적으로 플레이 해볼 것을 권유 하였을 것입니다.

초기작품인 Hexcells는 현재 즐기기에도 매우 재미 있습니다. 하지만... 현재 시점 기준 아래 4가지 이유로 비추천을 줄 수 밖에 없었습니다.

(1). 3개의 시리즈(Hexcells -> Hexcells Plus -> Hexcells Infinite)가 발매된 상태로 초기작품인 Hexcells 을 대체할 수 있는 작품이 있다는 것

(2). 후속작품인 Plus, Infinite 에 비해 플레이 타임이 매우 짧다는 것. 
 - Hexcells : 약 2시간 내외
 - Hexcells Plus : 9시간 내외
 - Hexcells Infinite : 27시간 

(3). 후속 작품에 비해 매우 쉬운 난이도에 퍼즐 갯수가 적다는 점

(4). Plus 부터 게임 Rule 이 추가되었기에 Hexcells 게임 자체가 Demo 게임처럼 느껴진다는 점

24606155.review:
Hexcells is the spiritual successor of the minesweep game that used to ship on windows.
It improves on the original concept by using a hexagonal board and some really clever extra hinting system.
With those extra hints it ends up feeling like a cross of minesweeps with sudoku.

In short, I L.O.V.E.D. it!

Its simple in it's presentation and yet brings a really complex intelectual challenge.
It is very clean and minimalistically designed but the result of this design is quite beaultiful and easy on the eyes.
There is no time pressure at all and you can do it wrong and retry each level at will.
The complexity of the puzzles scales gradually as you learn to read and to factor in each kind of hint but the last levels are a real challenge, large boards with all kinds of hints used together, forcing you to go back and forth through the board solving a little here and there until things start converging.
It is short but not too short for its price.

Worth every cent!

Hexcells is a minimalistic puzzle game in which one has to decide if orange hexes are either grey or blue ones with the help of several hints.

~ The puzzles slowly become more complicated with more clues to look at over the time. All three games (Hexcells, Hexcells Infinite and Hexcells Plus) have different mechanics added to the original in the beginning.

~ The game is extremely relaxing. There is no "Game Over" screen and no timer. You can solve the puzzles at your own pace with calm music in the background and fitting melodic sound effects.

[code]I highly recommend trying to solve the puzzles slowly without making any mistakes for the most enjoyable experience![/code]

~ Every single puzzle of the three Hexcells games is entirely solvable with logical thinking and without the need to guess during any of them.

~ Hexcells Infinite offers an additional mode in which you can generate puzzles with random seed codes.

Without doubt one of the most polished puzzle games I've seen, and even though I dislike Minesweeper, I love this game to bits.
Highly recommended.

24308275.review:
It IS an abstract puzzle, like minesweeper or sudoku or something like that, and it has a nice atmospheric sound and visuals to go along with it, but that's all it really is, honestly. It feels really insubstantial. Simply adding more levels isn't what I want, either. Nor is adding more mechanics. I just think it's hard to make an abstract puzzle game feel as fun as some of the other games out there. It took me 2-3 hours to 100% and I didn't really end it feeling like I was glad I played it. 

Plus, the music loop starts to get annoying after awhile. It's too short, plays too often, and isn't mixed in with other tracks. 

And the core gameplay loop is pretty much just - reveal the obvious stuff, then hunt around for the next thing you can reveal. That's not that fun to me compared to what you do in other games. It's not the lack of action or anything - I'm fine with slow-paced, turn-based, or other puzzle games. It's just the lack of problem solving - this game is all deduction and very little intuition. I like working with and experimenting with a hard problem and going over it in my head and trying different avenues of solutions and trying to come up with observations and rules and constraints that I can use to simplify the problem. You can find that core gameplay loop in lots of excellent puzzle games, but you won't find it here.

If you like minesweeper or sudoku you should definitely give this a try. Otherwise, even if you're a huge fan of puzzle games like me, I'd probably avoid this. You're not going to find that problem-solving engagement and stimulation here, unlike what you'd find in lots of other puzzle games. There's no experimenting, discovery, or anything like that. It's just "oh here's the next spot for which I can prove its contents" and "hmm, where's the next one?".

As a counterexample, an abstract puzzle game I DID enjoy was Splice (you might argue that it's not TRULY abstract since it uses a sort of biological metaphor, but I think of it as one). That game has plenty of that "problem solving high" you get as you experiment and observe and work through a complex problem.

23972711.review:
Do you like Minesweeper? How about Sudoku? Do you like logic and deduction puzzles involving numbers? Then let me introduce you to Hexcells. It’s a short and reasonably priced game that will give your brain some much needed exercise involving a bunch of “Aha!” moments.

It starts off like Minesweeper, but then gradually adds more and more layers of complexity. The gameplay involves deducing whether the hexes need to be saved or destroyed. Black hexes contain numbers that you can use to determine if there are blue hexes (the ones you mark/save). For example, if you have a 0 hex, then 0 hexes around it need to be saved while a 3 hex means 3 hexes must be saved. You do that for a while until the game starts throwing symbols and numbers on the outside at you. A 2 at the top of a column means there are two hexes to save in that column. A -2- in a hex means that there are two hexes to save that cannot be adjacent to each other. The trailer is good about showing the gameplay. Not a single puzzle relies on guesswork. It’s all about your brain processing the information so that you don’t make mistakes. My playtime reflects the time it took me to have 0 mistakes on all the puzzles.

If number logic puzzles are your thing, then Hexcells really is a good choice of game that’ll last you a couple days.

23912452.review:
The whole Hexcells series are really great puzzle games. The blame is totally on you for any mistakes you may make. They give you all the tools to figure out each puzzle if you can figure out the logic. The learning curve for figuring out that logic is spot on. Ideally play through the series straight, as the second and third game do start with more complicated puzzles and slightly new variations sooner. The feel as you go through a puzzle is likewise great. Occasionally you may get stuck for a solid length of time. The payoff is well worth it though. When you figure out a new bit, you get a solid rush as you suddenly can tick through another dozen cells with the new information provided.

Only two small complaints for the whole series. There is no separate toggle for the music and sound effects. Fortunately the music track is quiet enough that you can play something else over it and mostly not notice it. The music is nice and mellow if you want that, but not really the most engaging when you are stuck at the same spot for a long while. I went with the Classical Complete Works station from Pandora and it suited the mood quite well.

Second, the puzzles towards the end get quite long and there is no means to save mid puzzle that I could find. I assume this was so that you couldn't cheese your way to perfection. I would prefer the game at least give you the option to save in the middle if you were quitting and have the save auto-delete when you continue to prevent that. They did implement this in Infinite though. 5/5

23908706.review: Good game. Hard, but not totally unforgiving. I spent a lot of time chilling to the soundtrack and making those little blue hexagons appear. Any game that makes you place the blame solidly on yourself for screwing up instead of on it for being buggy is a good one in my book.

23901521.review:
In Hexcells, much like Minesweeper, you have to put a flag on dangerous cells, while marking the others as safe. 

You start with a pattern of hexagons and with a small amount of information that allows you to mark the first hexagons; in turn, the hexagons you mark give you additional information to mark some more, and so on and so forth.

The technical realization is very simple but effective: clean graphics and relaxing music. However, I had some problems with the music because it has a rhytmic structure that sets my pace at marking cells (I know it sounds crazy, but if I try to go off-beat I often make mistakes!).

The game is quite addictive and works brilliantly. The main concern is its shortness: just a handful of levels than can be completed in 1-2 hours at most. Two sequels exists, however.

23475556.review:
Hexcells is a nice simple little puzzle game, with the same relaxing gameplay as Minesweeper, and, it was entertaining for a while. I got the bundle on sale so it cost less than a candy bar, which is a good price for the 4 hours of fun I got out of it.

However there are a couple gameplay aspects that I don’t like, and one game braking issue that has ruined the Hexcells for me, thus I can’t recommend it.

I am going to compare Hexcells to Minesweeper in this review, I understand that it is not suppose to be the same game, but they are the only two games in this genre that I have experience with.

First, lets look at the parts I like.

[b]Pros:[/b]
The music is peaceful, and the sound effects fit in nicely.
The game looks clean and modern.
Unlike minesweeper, it is not stressful to click on tiles. (Though, this does have the effect of making it a little less satisfying when you complete the puzzle correctly.)
I like the extra tile options {3} for three connected tiles, -2- for two disconnected tiles, and the numbers on the outside of the grid for tiles in that row or column.
I like the fact that there is no timer, so I don’t feel rushed. (I hate puzzle games that make you rush)
I also like that the levels are not too hard to unlock.

Unfortunately that is as far as the pros go for me.

[b]Cons:[/b]
Unlike minesweeper, it counts a mistake if you flag a number tile! This is frustrating, especially when there is no “think about it” flag.  It may help if tiles that have their conditions met grey out, even if I have to do this manually, it would help I think.

There is not a “replay” button on screen.  This only became a problem when I started really trying to get perfect scores, which was pretty quickly.

I could not swap the mouse buttons.  I don’t know why, but I couldn’t get the mouse buttons to register as “keys.” By default the flag and destroy buttons are opposite Minesweeper, which really really messed up my clicking!  And, because flagging counted as a mistake I couldn’t even have one safe button!  In the end, I had to use keyboard keys and even though it’s not so bad, the entire thing was really frustrating.

And here is the game braking issue! [b]There is a really really easy way to cheat![/b]  It is so easy that once you know it is there, you can’t help but use it to your advantage, even if only accidentally!
Please, if you enjoy this puzzle game, and don’t know about this yet, don’t read below. 
[spoiler] YOU CAN SEE BEHIND YELLOW TILES!!!  As you mouse over yellow covered tiles they wiggle a little, and the yellow is just that, a cover, the tile is already there!  If the cover moves far enough you can see the tile color behind it, whether it is blue or black! Even if you don’t actively try to peek, just moving the mouse around like normal will give you glimpses.  This completely broke the game for me because what is the point of spending time working out hard tiles when I can just mouse over them a bunch to see if my guess is right!!![/spoiler]

23283541.review:
A nice relaxing puzzle. Very reminiscent of minesweeper, and additional elements added later on also reminded me of Picross. I completed the game on a lazy Saturday and it gave me enough challenge that it didn't feel like a breeze. Additionally, it never vexed me by being too difficult or requiring me to know the intricacies of how everything worked (those hidden rules you find after doing a puzzle for a long time). 

If there's one thing to note, it's that the "Perfectionist" achievement does NOT require you to get 0 mistakes on all levels, just to get all of those hexagonal "points". This is good, because there's several levels where I got 1 honest mistake and it didn't deduct anything.

The game also punishes random "spam n' solve" play by making it impossible to unlock later levels without X number of aforementioned hexagonal points. Why you would do that anyway is beyond me.

My only critique of the game is a lack of puzzles with all the elements added. Initially, the game starts off by showing you the base points, then shows you that lines and columns can have numbers too, and then shows you how to toggle everything; and suddenly, you're two-thirds of the way through the puzzles. Just a minor gripe, but getting Hexcells Plus & Infinite solves that problem nicely.

23184849.review:
Hexcells is a relatively simple puzzle game similar in some ways to mineweeper.   An array of hexes is presented and  you need to left click (reveal  a filled cell) or right click to reveal a non-filled cell.   However, it is vastly different from minesweeper in that each puzzle can be solved logicially wihout guesswork.   Each revealed cell shows the number of adjacent filled cells, but there can be other clues as well, for example, the number of filled cells in a column, row, or diagonal.  In this way it also reminds me a of sudoko puzzles.   There is no timer, and if you make a mistake you can either continue on or restart to try for a "pefect" solution, so one can procede at whatever pace you like.

Very enjoyable if you like this sort of logic puzzle.

A fun and challenging logical puzzle game similar to MineSweeper.
Using the numbers to work out which tiles to mark.

The big difference between Hexcells and Minesweeper is that you never need to guess at any point, there's always a way to work out where to click.
Also, numbers can be shown on the outside of the grid and show a different symbol with the number to tell you how the tiles you need to mark are laid out.

The only issue I have with this is that it's really short and there's no replay value in it.
If you wish to save a bit of money then I suggest only buying HexCells Infinite which contains the same as this but also has a random level generator for.. infinite.. replayability.

Short but a nice bit of puzzle fun. Simple Minesweeper meets Pattern kind of logical puzzle. Later levels are very enjoyable.

The game is very short. No replayability. The levels that are there, however, feel rewarding, fresh and enjoyable, despite the low difficulty. The game works as its own tutorial by introducing new elements step by step per level. It ends shortly after discovering all puzzle elements. It feels like there should have been 5 more puzzles.

Technical side is a bit flawed in that the cursor keeps flickering and the framerate is consistently low even though there's basically nothing on screen.

Ambient music and sounds are very good. Clicking cells emits a sound fitting the harmony of the ambient background track. Everything feels like music and that's beautiful.

Graphics are decent for a puzzle game with simple design. Unfortunately, poor framerate and cursor flickering. Seriously, this needs optimizing as it gnaws on the game experience.

Recommended if you're looking for a round of chill puzzles and don't mind the stuttering. I played this game via a friend's shared library.

23022484.review:
Hexcells is an excellent puzzle game with mechanics very similar to Minesweeper. Your goal is to discover fields where the 'bombs' are and correctly mark them by eliminating empty ones. They are represented by numbers which show how many bombs there are in adjacent cells. Additional rules are introduced in later levels such as number of bombs in whole column and that they must be either adjacent to one another or separate from each other.

Game has 30 levels which will take you between 1 and 1.5 hours to complete. Warm recommendation for purchasing Hexcells Complete Pack which contains all 3 games from this series.

22949919.review:
I was very happy to discover this game via my Steam Queue. Having spent a great many hours playing minesweeper back in the days, it was great to discover a game that fulfilled all the enjoyment minesweeper offered, but without the frustration of having to randomly guess (and possibly die) to complete the puzzle.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- Good puzzle game requiring some thought to solve the harder levels
- Making mistakes isn't a problem - you can keep going and complete level
- 1 'free' mistake every puzzle - you get full amount of hexcells which is good when you accidentally click left instead of right!
- All levels are completely solvable without guessing (seriously, anyone posting otherwise just hasn't figured out the puzzle - they're all solvable through pure logic, no guesswork required)
- Relaxing music, which is even interactive with each click.
- Has sequels to give you more puzzles to play once you finish!

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Short, I finished with 100% in under 3 hrs. However, you can pick it up as part of the Hexcells package with the two sequels for cheap, which gives you plenty of game play.
- Left-click/right-click can sometimes mix you up, so you click the wrong button. Can cause frustration when you're trying to get 100% if you're the type of person who hates doing puzzles over again.
- Addictive - not really a con, but once I started, I couldn't stop....

[h1]Recommended![/h1]

22882844.review:
Hexcells is a logic puzzle, similar in some ways to minesweeper or pic-a-pix/gridders/nonograms/macross/whatever other name you use for those games - you have to figure out which parts of the board are blue versus yellow, using logic based on numbers inside the cells (referring to how many blue cells touch it) and numbers on the outside of the cells (referring to how many blue cells are in that column). Then some numbers are marked to let you know if the blue cells have to be all continuous or have at least one space in them.

It's a fun game, but very short.  The puzzles increase in difficulty at a decent rate, never getting either boring or too frustrating.  But I was left wanting more puzzles.  (Fortunately, there are two other games.)  The music is terrific, and surprisingly relaxing.  Sometimes the chimes when marking a hex got on my nerves, but most of the time they were enjoyable.

Overall, it's a great little game, but the length means it's not worth the full price, in my opinion.  I tend to require about 2 hours worth of enjoyable playtime per dollar spent to feel like I got my money's worth, and if I'd bought this at full price, it wouldn't have reached that.  If you can get it for 40-50% off, however, I think it's definitely worth picking up, or if you have less harsh criteria for money spent (or do puzzles a bit slower).  I haven't yet played the sequels, though I picked those up, too - I understand the third one has a puzzle generator with thousands of possible boards, which would take care of the shortness issue.

One other minor critique - one of the achievements is to finish every level with a perfect score, but I could find no indication in the level menu of which levels had finished with a mistake.  (I may have been missing it, of course.)  If you don't care about Steam achievements, it's no issue, but if you do, I suggest immediately replaying a level if you make a mistake.

Since I've seen a lot of reviewers do personal scales, and it's helped me a lot to decide what to buy, I put my own here. [b]I give Hexcells a 4 out of 5[/b]. Additionally, I usually only give a thumbs up if I got at least two hours of enjoyment out of it for every dollar I spent, and this game did that. (It wouldn't have if I hadn't bought it on discount, however.)

5: Amazing game, easily worth the full price.
[b]4: Good game, solid addition to the genre, might want to wait for a discount.[/b]
3: Pretty entertaining game, but some issues. Buy at a discount unless you love the genre.
2: More cons than pros, a lot of issues. Only buy with a strong discount, and only if the game truly sounds like something you'd enjoy.
1: Don't get this game unless it's free. Even then, consider spending your time playing something decent.

順便說一下玩法


相連是只中間沒有建隔黑色方塊，不管兩塊之間離多遠都叫相連

數字表示週圍藍色的數量
-數字-表示週圍至少一個不相連藍色的數量
{數字}表示週圍相連藍色的數量

22843217.review:
基本玩法跟扫雷类似的游戏。不过有一些不同点。
它不需要像扫雷一样有时要猜雷，每个格子是否有“雷”可以完全依靠逻辑推理得出。因为它不是随机生成的，而是经过精心设计的谜题。不过这也意味着谜题数量是有限的，不能无限玩下去（第三部除外）。
不过谜题难度循序渐进，逐渐增加新元素，玩的不失乐趣很也有成就感。画面极简风格，符合当下潮流。
需要注意的是默认鼠标左右键的功能和扫雷不同，左键是“标记”，右键是“翻开”。（不过在设置里可以更改）

Hexcells是系列第一部，难度不是很高，可以作为入门，以后再去尝试第二部Hexcells Plus和第三部Hexcells Infinite。
有点遗憾的是到第三部才支持云存档。

+循序渐进的难度
+全成就容易
+简单清新的画面
-谜题有限
-没有云存档

————————————————

基本规则并不难，如果看不懂，简单讲一下

黄色格子是没翻开的，黑色格子是空格，蓝色格子是标记的“雷”。
空格里的数字表示周围六个格子里有几个是雷。
带{ }的数字表示周围的雷是连续排列的。
带- -的数字表示周围的雷是不连续排列的。
边缘的数字表示一整列里有几个是雷。（左击数字可以打开辅助线，右击可关闭数字）
同样，带{ }、- -的数字表示这一整列里的雷是连续或者不连续的。
蓝色格子（雷）里的数字表示周围两圈范围（18格）内有几个雷（不算自己）。（左击可打开范围指示，右击可关闭）

以上就是整个三部所有需要用到的规则（有一些规则第一部不会出现）。

右上角的REMAINING表示还剩多少雷没标记（这也是一个重要的参考），MISTAKES表示犯错次数。
犯错不会立即GAME OVER，而是可以继续尝试，所以你瞎猜也可以完成游戏，不过拿到的星星会变少（影响后面关卡解锁以及全成就）。不过只犯错一次也可以拿全星星，所以当实在找不出突破口的时候，可以猜一次。

所有关卡全部通关+全星星就可以拿全成就了。

[spoiler]取巧方法：先不管出错次数，玩到快结束，截个图，然后重新开始谜题，对着刚截的图重玩一遍，可以无脑全星星。（反正谜题是固定的嘛）[/spoiler]

22824832.review:
マインスイーパーとピクロス（ピクチャーロジック）を
組み合わせたようなルールなので、この手のロジックパズルが
好きな人であればすんなり理解できます。
ルールが複雑過ぎて難解ということもないので、
ハードコアなパズルファンでなくても楽しめると思います。
（マインスイーパーもピクロスも知らない人だと
多少手こずるかもしれませんが）

パズル初心者に向けているのか、間違えた選択をすると
その場でミスとなる仕様のため、上級者の人には
好みが分かれるところだと思います。
（個人的には不要だと思います）

上記の通り、間違った選択をするとその場で訂正されるため、
数手先まで読んだ上で推測する「背理法」的な考え方は要求されず、
その点で難易度はそこまで高くはありません。
数独やピクロスのような超絶難易度の問題を期待すると、
やや拍子抜けするかもしれません。

ひとつ難点なのが、問題の途中のセーブができないことです。
終盤は解くために15分ほどかかる問題もあるため、
セーブができず、中断する際に「リセットされるけどOK？」
といった警告すら出ないのには閉口します。

また、難点というほどではないですが、
Windowsのマインスイーパーでは
「左クリックでオープン、右クリックで地雷の旗を立てる」
という操作が、今作では逆なのが若干戸惑います。

全体的にカジュアルな作りではありますが、
パズルファンでも十分楽しめるかと思います。
（ただ、２～３時間程度で全問題終わるでしょう）

when I saw this game's store page, its overwhelmingly positive reviews and its nice pictures; I thought to myself: its gonna be a very clever mind teasing mathematics puzzle game. but in reallity its just another MINESWEEPER CLONE!!!
the developer changed the minesweeper's squares to hexagons then adds a litte clever sound design to it and finally a beautiful and simple visuals has been added to the game as spice and made the Hexcells.
Pros:
+ All Levels are Designed by Level designer, so you won't need chance to ending a level (unlike minesweeper), but you need attention and thinking.
+ You can make mistakes in levels and it isn't instant death
+ adds some new and cool elements to minesweeper gameplay
+ wonderful sound and visual designs
+ No time limit, so it's like relax mode of minesweeper

Cons:
- very low replay value (unlike Minesweeper)
- there aren't many levels to play and levels are short (I completed the game under 90 mins and refunded it through steam)
- after all tryings to changing Minesweeper into something completely new; this game feels like a Minesweeper that isn't free to play!!! :(

22755652.review:
[h1]А можно просто объяснять всем, кто этого еще не понял, что «Тетрис», пасьянсы, шахматные и карточные программы, Bejeweled, Lines, Jawbreaker и прочие — не компьютерные игры. На компьютере? Да, и что с того? Так вот и в нашем случае. «Hexcells» на компьютере «только ездит», по-настоящему он его не использует. © Андрей Ленский, журнал ЛКИ[/h1]

[b]Hexcells[/b] - логическая казуальная игра, совмещающая в своих правилах "Сапёра", японские кроссворды и щепотку новизны разработчиков, в которой необходимо перевернуть определенным образом гексы на игровом поле. 

По аналогии с сапёром есть игровое поле, состоящее из гексов, на котором присутствуют чёрные гексы с цифрами в середине, показывающими дополнительное количество голубых гексов в пределах одного радиус-круга. Всё остальное - гексы чёрные. Благо в настройках при запуске можно поменять раскладку, а то всё по старинке ищем отсутствие "мин", вместо их присутствия. При прохождении 6 головоломок откроется еще 6, могут добавиться новые условия, например, количество голубых гексов на линии и т.д. Задача - решить все головоломки. В каждой головоломке можно сделать одну ошибку. Обучение текстовое на простом английском, да и игра начинается с интуитивно понятных задач.

Графически игра сделана в стиле минимализма.

Музыка же представляет из себя эмбиент, вот только если заранее известно какие гексы где находятся, быстрое переворачивание приведёт к игре, как на клавесине. Озвучки никакой нет.  

Управляется игра мышью. Сохранений нет.

Недостатки: хоть и присутствует разнообразие графического разрешения, но почему-то 1280х1024 нет. Хотелось бы генератора головоломок после прохождения. Хочется сохранений, ведь некоторые партии могут занять до получаса! Проходится игра всего часа за 4.

Для обладателей математического склада ума эта игра развлечёт на работе, когда клиентов нет, на порядок больше, чем ранее упомянутые "LYNE" и "Faerie Solitaire". Достойная компьютерная версия некомпьютерной игры. [b]Hexcells[/b], рекомендую.

22528217.review:
Hexcells proves that puzzle games don't need to be extremely complex to thoroughly enjoy.

Now if you've ever played Minesweeper then right away you'll realise the basic premise is the same in both games. You click on a hexagon and it'll reveal a number and that number is how many 'mines' are around that specific hexagon, sound familiar? What Hexcells adds onto the original Minesweeper experience is a more puzzle oriented design to its levels, with each progressively testing your knowledge of new mechanics that get introduced throughout the worlds. That beind said each level in a world has a set amount of 'mines' in predefined locations, some puzzles might take you multiple tries to first realise the pattern but once you do it's abundantly satisfying when you finally solve it.

This game has a very minimalistic approach to both its audio and graphics; there isn't much to complain about because it gets the job done. Simple hexagon shapes with an electronic ambience in the style of Solar Fields, with the added bonus of the game's audio playing in rhythm to your actions.

Honestly my biggest complaint with this game is that there aren't enough puzzles, if you're like me than it'll leave you with that feeling of "I want more!". Thankfully though this game is really cheap, I'd highly recommend a purchase to anyone interested in either puzzles or games like Minesweeper/Sudoku/Picross.

22410430.review:
Puzzle games that take a familiar mechanic and add a simple set of twists can definitely go one way or the other: really good, or horribly bad. Occasionally, I buy one on a whim and am granted with a brilliant experience, as I was with [b]Lyne[/b]. This has happened not just once again, but three times with [b]Hexcells[/b], [b]Hexcells Plus[/b] and [b]Hexcells Infinite[/b]. For the sake of brevity, what follows covers all three, but the TLDR is that if you like puzzle games, buy Hexcells.

[u]Graphics[/u] 9/10

Visuals are always big with me, and these games are beautiful with simple, clean imagery and colours. But this beauty has function: the orange, blue and charcoal colour scheme means you know very clearly what each cell is. The small animations when you hover over or click on a cell are nicely done as well. While it's not perfect, I have only very minor issues with particular aspects of each iteration of Hexcells; so small I won't even mention. But if you're a fan of minimalist design, this is a great example.

[u]Audio[/u] 9/10

The minimalism here continues, with more variety however. Although I generally turn off music in games, I did take the time to sample it in all three iterations of Hexcells. I'm a fan of ambient electronic, and found it very fitting. Combined with the visuals, it made me think of games like [b]flOw[/b]. The samples used when clicking on cells continue the minimalist electronic theme, with some levels using piano-type sounds while others sounded more like raindrops or wee bells. With that said, after having to redo some levels again and [i]again[/i], I turned off the sound completely. And speaking of level design …

[u]Gameplay[/u] 10/10

Have you played [b]Minesweeper[/b]? This game is to Minesweeper, what [b]DOOM[/b] was to [b]Wolfenstein[/b]. The basic gameplay was very similar, but suddently there is more depth, more challenges, more variety. And while I liked Minesweeper back when I first got Windows 95, I found it too repetitive. Hexcells however, introduces enough new mechanics, not to mention board design, that I could play this game continually.

[u]Replayability[/u] 9/10

In fact, that's part of what [b]Hexcells Infinite[/b] is about, with a level generator built in that uses a random seed to create as many levels as you wish to play. Though the pedant in me wants to say: an 8 digit, whole integer seed won't give me [i]infinite[/i] levels, but that is such a tiny quibble. ;) Still, overall, with dozens of levels pre-built in each of the three versions of Hexcells, and the near-infinite custom levels in one version, there is plenty of replayability.

[u]Overall[/u] 9/10

If you like puzzle games, buy Hexcells. If you have a friend who likes puzzle games, buy Hexcells for him/her. As of this writing, you can get all three versions for $9.99CDN, and at that price, it's a good deal. If you can snag it on sale, even better. Add on the fact that it works on Windows, Mac and Linux, and there's really no good reason not to support a developer like this. My only hope is they can follow it up with another game that is as brilliant.

22109190.review:
[b]Hexcells[/b] is a minimalistic logic puzzle very similar to classic Minesweeper. You need to find blue cells and numbers show you how many of them are nearby. 

What makes Hexcells better than Minesweeper? 
[list]
[*]For one, there is no instadeath. If you make a mistake, you just keep going. 
[*]Most importantly with a little bit (and sometimes with [b]a lot[/b]) of thinking you can figure out where each blue cell is located. Unlike minesweeper where sooner or later you come to a point when you have to close your eyes and guess randomly. 
[/list]
Music is very nice and the game itself is relaxing. 

The first game is short and puzzles are easy to crack. It took me ~3 hours to perfect all 36 levels. It helps to learn mechanics of the game but it won’t last long. I recommend buying [b]Hexcells Complete Pack[/b] (Hexcells, Hexcells Infinite, Hexcells Plus) because you will definitely want more.

It's Minesweeper + Sudoku/Picross, except harder than both, with super calming ambient music. What's more to like? Oh yeah, the sequel, Hexcells Plus. Get that too! Only bad part, IMO, is that you can fail your way to success. IMO the game should have a retry button appear immediately, even if it thinks the "soft mistake" is a feature and not a bug. Being able to see the results of my mistake is enough of a problem, without having it sitting there on the screen, etching into my brain. The mechanics and time spent crafting the puzzles was amazing enough to make this only a minor quibble, though.

This game is like a hybrid of Minesweeper and Picross - which is good.  However, "Hexcells" on its own is not very challenging and acts more of an introduction to the style of puzzles.  If you feel you're good at the core concept of Minesweeper-type playstyle (or only want to get one) check out Hexcells Plus or Hexcells Infinite instead.

Basically spent ~3 hours getting 100% achievements.  It was fun and worth the price I paid for it.  I recommend getting it bundled with the others since, as I wrote previously, pretty much an introduction to the puzzle style and Plus and Infinite add more challenging mechanics.

21469954.review:
Я люблю логические игры. Понапрягать мозг бывает очень даже полезно. Но то, к чему в итоге сводится Hexcells - просто безобразие. Ну ладно. Начнём.

Да, игра мне очень нравится, но всё же я пишу отрицательную рецензию. И вот почему:

Что же за игра это такая?
- Hexcells - это клон Сапёра, только тут игровое поле не разбито на квадратики, а на шестигранники-гексы. Что несколько бывает упрощает игру, снижая количество активных участков полей вокруг одного гекса с 8-и до 6-и. И это удобно, ибо окружные гексы теперь связаны друг с другом рёбрами, а не только углами в том же четырёхстороннем Сапёре: на этом будут завязаны некоторые задачки на обнаружение мин.

Так, с коротким описание покончили, вперёд к достоинствам и недостаткам.

Достоинства:
+ Дейстивттельно годная логическая игра, если вам поднадоел Сапёр и его рандомностью (да, все задачи в игре статичны, местонахождение мин не меняется);
+ Ошибки, а не смерть. Главное отличие Hexcells от Сапёра- это "бессмертность" игрока. То есть, совершив ошибку, вы не взрываете всё поле, а продолжаете играть. Количесвто ошибок влияет только на конечный результат уровня - сможете ли вы собрать все бонусные очки за аккуратную игру.
+ Достижения. Довольно... Лёгкие достижения и их всего 6. Просто напросто нужно пройти всю игру, совершив в каждом уровне максимум одну ошибку. После двух промахов с уровня будут бонусные очки удаляться, благо можно запомнить нахождение бомб и пройти заново.
+ Очень интересные задачки на обнаружение бомб. То они вокруг случайным порядком, то они могут быть ОБЯЗАТЕЛЬНО (да, это важно) сцеплены друг с другом или наоборот находяться вокруг одного гекса раздельно. Также может указываться сколько бомб находяться на определённых линиях или зонах.

Ну а теперь минус... Один! Но он всё ломает!
- Это завышенная планка колдовства и шаманизма в конце игры! Да, друзья мои, мне очень нравятся логические игры, особенно сложные, но это!.. В общем, в начале игры всё довольно легко: нас обучают различным вариациям нахождения бомб, всякие лёгкие задачки, средние, посложнее, где ошибиться раз-два или три конечно обидно, ведь если хотите все достижения, то, будьте добры, перепройдите идеально.
Дальше - не сказать чтобы лучше. Внезапно появляется новый ВИД обнаружения - "?". Серьёзно, "?". То есть включай интуицию и гадай есть ли вокруг этого гекса бомбы или же их и нет. И таких задач становиться всё больше и больше, да и сами задачи вымахивает до огромных размеров, что ничего в итоге не остаётся делать как включать внутреннюю Вангу или Нострадамуса (кстати, это самые великие предсказатели из истории человечества), а может и обоих сразу, ибо логически мыслить под конец игры уже просто НЕВОЗМОЖНО!

Мне очень понравилась эта игра, но из-за такого "весёлого" конца игры мне приходиться сказать следующее: "Так что, скрепя сердцем, я НЕ рекомендую эту игру любителям головоломок, ибо логика в конце игры пропадает вовсе", но если поиграть и попробовать игру всё же хочется, то покупайте игру с большой скидкой. И лучше в комплекте с двумя другими её продолжениями... Боже, как же они мне любы и ненавистны... Но об этом в другой раз.
Однако, если выхотите похвастаться перед друзьями своим списков идеальных игр, то можете её взять. За часик другой вы эти достижения себе заберёте.

P.S. Чтобы не маяться с повторным прохождением сложных задач оставляйте на поле одну незаполненную фишку, фотографируете (или делаете скриншот) экран и уже заполняете поле правильно по своему предыдущему запечатлённому опыту.

21434960.review:
Excellent mini game to keep the old dying brain cells alive.

The concept is super simple. The UI is so subtle and minimalistic. Sound and music fits right in with the slickness of it all. It's so well done.

The puzzles increase in difficulty as you progress. Every time a new concept is introduced, it is explained with a single sentence. No need for lengthy tutorials here. Also, every puzzle can be solved by logic alone. You don't have to guess.

Eventually you will get to a level where you just sit and stare at the screen, desperately trying to find an opening. When you finally find that opening, you can't help but feel a little cool. You make a couple of moves, only to get stuck again. That's when you realize there is more to the logic than what meets the eye. You learn to think outside the boxes.. or hexes, if you will. When you perfect a level that otherwise seemed impossible to do, you feel like a genius.

Any game that makes me feel like a genius deserves a big thumbs up.

В последнее время при написании рецензий (серьезных или не очень) стала крайне популярна фраза по типу: "X встречает Y" - или: "Если бы у X и Y был бы ребенок он бы выглядел вот так". Я не буду оригинальничать и скажу, что Hexcells выглядит как дитя незабвенного Сапера и японского кроссворда (нонограммы).

Сначала вам предлагают "разминировать" поле опираясь на подсказки как в классическом Сапере. Использование вместо квадратов шестиугольников (хексов) отнюдь не нововведение - за свою более чем долгую историю поле для игры в Сапер на какие фигуры только не разбивали. По мере роста сложности вам дают другие типы подсказок - цифры в поле помечаются спец. символами указывающими в каком порядке, непрерывно или раздельно, находятся вокруг мины. А во второй половине пробиваются черты нонограмм - над строками, столбцами и диагоналями нашего поля появляются числа говорящие о том сколько на этой линии "мин".

Игра сочетающая механику двух популярных головоломок в простом, но эстетическом оформлении приправленная отличной эмбиент музыкой тем не менее не обошлась без пары серьезных минусов. По сути она потеряла две главные вещи за которые мы любим головоломки: вариативность и сложность. Все этапы в игре предустановлены, и, за исключением разве что пары последних, довольно просты. Да, в [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900/] Hexcells Plus [/url] мы получаем более сложные головоломки, но их там только 36. И лишь в [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/304410/] Hexcells Infinite [/url] автор наконец таки добавил рандомизатор полей.

Стоит ли покупать все игры или только последнюю это выбор каждого. Но так или иначе Hexcells остается замечательной игрой.

21242352.review:
Excellent game!  Reminds me of Minesweeper and also Sudoko.  It's a relaxing game to play, though it is a bit short.  The early levels teach you the basics, and you'll be introduced to more rules as you progress into the later levels.  

There's plenty of "ah ha!" moments as you use deductive reasoning to determine if an orange hex should be marked as blue, or uncovered to reveal a numeric value about the adjacent cells.  The goal is to find "x" number of blue hexes in the level, where x is different for each level.  As you uncover more and more numeric cells, the more information you have about which remaining orange hexes are blue or numeric.

The only downside is that the game was over before I knew it.  I completed all levels, re-doing a few to get the elusive "0 mistakes" in each level, and it only took me 5.5 hours.  And that's being generous (I got up to use bathroom, blow nose, etc, while game was running a few times).

I did buy the game though in the Hexcells Complete bundle, which comes with two sequels, which are both worth getting as well.  The bundle itself was even on sale, so I think I actually only paid about $0.79 for Hexcells itself.  That said, even at it's normal price of $2.99, it's still worth buying.

21223868.review:
Hexcells

A nice, relaxing puzzle game, set to a calm set of background noises and music that tickles the brain just enough to see it to the end. A super short game that doesn't take long to finish the game or even the achievements. It has a few flaws, but then again, what game isn't?

[h1]Abstract - [/h1]
Hexcells is a short puzzle game involving numbers, hexagons, and a bit of thinking. It's short, sweet, not all that problematic, and fun for anyone looking for a little puzzle fix.

[h1]What it is - [/h1] 
Its a puzzle game, pretty straight forward. No huge plot or anything.

[h1]Who you are - [/h1]
The puzzle solver!

[h1]What you do in game - [/h1]
Solve the puzzles using the context clues and hints provided by clicking the different cells. Two counters appear at the top, the remaining blue cells that need to be revealed, and the mistake counter, which affects how many "reward cells" you get upon finishing a level. The higher your mistake count, the less you earn. 

[h1]Gameplay - [/h1]
The aim of the game is to find all the blue cells while making few to no mistakes as possible. Finding all the blue cells and revealing the hint cells will finish the level. You need a set amount of "reward cells" in order to open up the newer levels, increasing in amount the further you go along. The game itself is an enjoyable experience, and, for the most part, not all that difficult. It becomes a little painful at the end, but the biggest complaint is how often "guesstimating" is your only option. You can easily narrow down where the blue cells will be, but more often than not you'll end up guessing about where the blue cells could be. Some are smart guesses, others are just "welp, I'm stumped!" guesses. It kinda detracted from the idea of solving the puzzle using smarts.

Messing up isn't the end of the world. You can simply come back to the level later to try for fewer mistakes. That said, one can simply get the solution by purposefully using the screenshot function, but that's more of a "last resort", so don't abuse it!

[h1]Envionment - [/h1]
White background, orange hexagons. Kinda strains the eye after a while, so take breaks!

[h1]Conclusion - [/h1]
Really, especially for the price, its a pretty smooth game. Guesstimations aside, its a game that keeps you thinking, doesn't punish you too hard for playing the game and making mistakes as you can always come back to play at your own pace. The game also has several parts so you can easily extend your play sessions with different puzzles. If you're a hardcore puzzle lover, give this a pass. Too easy, exploitable, relies too much on guessing. If you just enjoy a good puzzle to pass the time, pick it right up!

21166501.review:
I finished the whole thing and all of its thirty-ish levels in one day because it was that fun.  I'm exhausted.

Hexcells is a logic puzzle that's similar to other number games like Minesweeper and Picross, as you use processes of elimination and deduction to fill in patterns of tiles.  The distinction here is that since the tiles are hexagons, they're not restricted by square grids, and most puzzles look like abstract shapes or very loosely defined objects.  Black-background hexes have numbers on them from 0-6, indicating how many of the gold tiles around them can be clicked to turn blue, which counts toward stage completion.

Those hexes are a mixed blessing--finding all of them is the whole point of the game (though you do have to mark every single tile, whether you believe it to be a blue "hit" or a black "guide"), but unless you know how many blue tiles are in a given area, these don't often give any information on the tiles around them.  The numbers themselves eventually adopt additional characteristics that give you more information on how to complete a stage, but it's well worth remembering that making a decision about one tile necessarily is effectively making a decision about all of the tiles next to it as well.  Levels are divided up into groups and sometimes able to be completed out of order, and completing each level perfectly will often mean you unlock the next set even without fully having to finish the previous one.

The game is easy to learn, with simple controls and all of the rules explained as you need them, and there are no hectic time limits to worry about.  (I don't know if there's a way to save during levels.)  You'll probably build up enough stress just by trying to finish levels without making mistakes, as difficulty ramps up quickly and there's no quick way to restart stages, that I know of, without exiting back out to the level-select menu.  This may serve the purpose of discouraging cheating, though.  It would be nice to be able to turn the music on and off during a level, but the little 'bloop' sounds the tiles make when clicked go really well with the gentle soundtrack, so much so that you might not notice them at first.

You can make guesses about what tiles are where, but it's much more satisfying to finish a stage or even a small section of one because you understood the rules than because you happened to get lucky.  The game doesn't need reflexes, but it expects and encourages patience and discipline (try not to scream if you misclick toward the end of a level you've been chipping away at for half an hour), all for the cost of a small meal.

If you love puzzle games, then this is definitely one that you should try out.
Hexcells starts out looking like Minesweeper with hexagons, but new mechanics along the way make it a unique experience. Each level presents its own challenge, and completing each one (especially a difficult one) feels rewarding.
If replay value is your sort of thing, this particular entry in the series does not excel in that department, as there are only 30 levels. If you have a lot of time on your hands, those 30 levels will be over in no time.

20699899.review:
[b]Hexcells[/b] ist ein auf Logik basierendes Puzzle-Spiel, das sehr stark an [i]Minesweeper[/i] erinnert, jedoch etwas komplexer ist. Es macht sehr viel Spass und ich kann es bedenkenlos weiterempfehlen. 

[u]An dieser Stelle direkt ein Hinweis:[/u] 
Eine Langzeitmotivation besteht bei diesem Spiel nicht, da hier keine Randompuzzle generiert werden. Ist man einmal mit allen Leveln fertig und hat diese zu 100% gelöst, dann ist man im Prinzip durch. Auch hat man in diesem Fall bereits alle Steam-Errungenschaften erreicht, so dass auch von dieser Seite keine Motivation zu einem erneuten Durchspielen erfolgt. Ich gehe davon aus, dass jeder das Spiel in 2-5 Stunden durchgespielt hat, ist natürlich individuell unterschiedlich.

Prinzipiell stehen 3 Spielslots zur Verfügung, so dass 3 Personen ihren individuellen Spielfortschritt  speichern können. Hinter jedem Spielslot verbergen sich verschiedene Puzzle-Level, die man lösen muss. Die Puzzle selbst werden nicht random generiert, sondern es sind immer die gleichen Patterns je (Teil-)Level.

Die einzelnen Puzzle erlauben Fehler, die hochgezählt werden und man nicht direkt - wie z.B. bei Minesweeper - sofort von vorne anfangen muss. Um am Ende aller durchgespielten Puzzle jedoch einen 100% Erfolg erhalten zu können (und damit auch den Steam-Erfolg "Perfectionist", muss man jedes Puzzle fehlerfrei lösen. 
Jedes Rätsel kann man tatsächlich mit reiner Logik/Mathematik lösen, man ist damit nicht - wie oft z.B. bei Minesweeper - auf Klick-Glück angewiesen.

Die Komplexität an verschiedenen Hinweisen, die man bei der Lösung beachten muss, nimmt mit aufsteigendem Level zu. Neulinge in diesem Puzzlegenre werden so intuitiv an die Berücksichtigung herangeführt und werden nicht gleich von Anfang an überfordert.

[u]Kritikpunkt:[/u]
Es wäre schön, wenn man irgendwo erkennen könnte, welche Puzzle man anfangs nicht gleich fehlerfrei gelöst hat, damit man hinterher gezielt auf den 100% Erfolg hinarbeiten kann.
