20668942.review:
Hexcells is a really nice spin on the classic minesweeper we all know (and love).. Instead of clearing out squares, you now have to clear hexagons, which surprisingly creates new challenges to overcome. Things get even more interesting once new mechanics are thrown into the mix like a certain amount of marked hexagons being next to each other or having at least one gap in between marked hexagons. They're added overtime, just so the player can get comfortable with the new skills they're learning though the previous levels. If you're hungry for a new kind of minesweeper, complete with an ambient soundtrack, a smooth difficulty curve, and a whole lotta hexagons, you can't go wrong with Hexcells.

20640568.review:
Если вы хотите чтобы в вашем выдающемся профиле в витрине достижений в пункте «идеальные игры» красовалась еще одна дополнительная единичка, и вы поражали бы своих друзей своей принципиальной крутостью, то вы имеете 100% возможность этого достичь. 

Маленький бонус - за прохождение Hexcells в виде достижений вам дадут цифры от 1 до 6-ти, которыми можно украсить свой профиль в витрине достижений! Что-нибудь написать вместе с буквами от "ачивок" "LYNE", как-нибудь «соригинальничать» ;)) это Trend в профилях Steam_а или попса – решать вам.

Если все вышеозначенное для вас важно, то эта игра вам необходима!!!

Теперь о самой игре. Сначала я подумал, что это обычный аналог «Сапера», но не тут-то было, игра шире и разнообразней. Только в ней уровни создаются не «рандомно»: они уже такие, какими их сделали разработчики, поэтому прохождение заключается в запоминании мест, где находятся «мины». 

(При желании можно обратиться к Guide_ам по прохождению) (Сообщество Steam_а в помощь)

Если все вышенаписанное "отмести", то игра расслабляет. После кликов мышью нужной кнопкой на «правильные» Hex_ы производится приятный звук, напоминающий звуки нот фортепиано или барабанов, так что получается подобие некой мелодии.

В заключении: Вам может помешать "добить идеальную игру" если только вы будете путать указательный и средний пальцы и кнопки "манипулятора типа - МЫШь" - левую на правую! ;)))

20578239.review:
我是一位扫雷爱好者，之前看到评论里说和扫雷类似就趁着打折的时候入了，非常满足。

游戏有些类似于六边形的扫雷，但是推理上来说多了横纵斜上的个数，也多了连通和非连通的信息，让整个推理更有意思，由于关卡是设计好的也没有扫雷里面死猜（二选一两个都是可以的，只能碰几率）的问题。

总的来说这第一作可以算是入门的作品，比较有意思但难度不是很高，可以较快全成就，可能就最后几关会比较吃力。后几作加了特性和难度。

游戏比较适合喜欢逻辑，推理解谜的玩家，另外BGM非常魔性。

假如游戏可以开放关卡编辑器那就更好了，这游戏应该很适合自己开发关卡。

20569519.review: I picked up the complete pack for around $3. This was a fantastic buy - The game is similar to Minesweeper except the board is segmented, hexagonal, and all levels are made to prevent the annoying guessing mechanic of Minesweeper. The levels also have additional information that really requires you to think, but the game at the same time is very intuitive and doesn't require the use of a guide at all. The feeling when you solve an entire part of the board with one discovery is fantastic. I don't usually grab puzzle games on steam, but I'm glad that I got this one. It is very short, but in a Portal sort of way where it is also sweet. It is roughly 2-3 hours of gameplay, but infinite adds in custom levels too which can expand upon your play if you can't stay away. Overall, I would definitely recommend buying this game if you can grab the complete pack on sale.

20552178.review:
[h1]A Paladin’s Steam Review: Hexcells, Plus and Infinite. Cheesing in the Cells.[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: Minimalist Casual Atmospheric Number Puzzlers
[*]Developed & Published by: Matthew Brown
[*]Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux
[*]Business Model: Base Game
[*][i]Copy Purchased by Myself[/i] 
[/list]
[i][url=http://wp.me/p4fZDz-2Uz]Read the full & unabridged review about the entire Hexcells Series on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/i]

[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
Hexcells is a minimalist puzzle game that I like to think of as a combination of Minesweeper and Sudoku. A comparison that has probably been made elsewhere. Every level is basically the same. You’re presented with a variable number of cells with a number in the top right corner telling you how many blue cells there are in the puzzle. The challenge is figuring out which cells are blue and which are numbers. If you guess incorrectly, it’s counted as a mistake that will affect how many points you get at the end of a level. The numbers on or adjacent to cells are telling you how many blue cells are connected to them. It’s up to the player to figure out the pattern by examining the numbers. In general terms, if there are two unknown cells connected to a cell that has the number “2” on it, they’re both blue cells. There are several different mechanics used to confuse the player and make them logic out the solution. Upon completing a level, you’ll be rewarded with points that are used to unlock additional groups of levels. As such, this does requires you to complete most of the puzzles with a minimal amount of mistakes in order to progress forward. 

[b]Hexcells, the Original’s Features[/b]
The original Hexcells contains 30 puzzles and is the easiest of the three games. I would recommend playing this first just to get a feel of what each title will expect of you. However, it’s not required as each entry does a good job of explaining itself and gradually introduces you to the various mechanics.  

[b]My Main Issue With Hexcells[/b]
Here’s the problem I have with the entire Hexcells series. It’s a pretty good puzzle experience, if you play it how it’s intended to be played. However, I feel that they have a problematic design flaw: all of the puzzles can be cheesily completed. If you’re stuck at a certain sequence, you can just click through the rest of the puzzle making as many mistakes as you like. (I had some puzzles at 50-60 mistakes). What about the points you would get from a near perfect completion? Well, once you nearly finish the puzzle, take a screenshot and then instantly replay the level with your own personal guide. It’s possible to win all three games this way without much effort on your part. 

[b]PC Settings & Audio/Video[/b]
It’s a minimalist game so there really aren’t many settings to change. Since its running on the Unity engine, the Unity launcher menu pops up when you start the game every time. It allows you to change resolutions and turn fullscreen on/off. The graphics quality is set to beautiful and can’t be changed. However, I was able to play this on a basic, five year old laptop running Linux Mint and there was absolutely no trouble running it. Alternative keys can be changed here as well. Hexcells Infinite was the only game of the three that allows you to swap the left and right mouse button functions.  

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Overall, I think the Hexcells series is a decently executed puzzle idea with plenty of content. I take issue with the lack of anti-cheat but it's not enough to make it an anti-recommendation. (Thanks to a friend for making a case to change my mind on this). It’s a fun logic number puzzle series. And I did play the three games how it was intended too, with a few exceptions. I had quite a bit of fun deducing the my way through the levels and had several “aha!” moments despite it’s more casual nature. Additionally, it maintains a mellow and atmospheric experience that I can appreciate. While there is the less honorable part of myself thinking “you can just easily ‘cheat’ this game and not spend hours on it”, that doesn't disqualify it from being a decent puzzle game. So, if you can avoid cheating yourself, get the Hexcells series. But if you can’t restrain yourself from looking up help on even the slightest bit of challenge, I probably wouldn't get it. Otherwise, that's my thoughts on this series. 

[h1][url=http://wp.me/p4fZDz-2Uz]Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/h1]

20536328.review:
I was expecting a puzzle game of casual difficulty--something to pass the time while I chatted with friends--and that is what I found, but I failed to predict how complex and interesting could be without an intimidating difficulty curve. 

What I certainly did not expect was the beautiful soundtrack.  Words alone are not enough to describe this.  Every tile you touch adds a pleasant echo of a note to the tranquil melodies singing you to sleep as you progress.  It's the most soothing and relaxing puzzle game I have ever played, each step as rewarding as suspenseful in mild strokes.  Not only that, but the level design is brilliant.  Start from multiple points and work your way through your own way, depending on which clues you find first.

You will especially love it if you have ever played a Picross game.  I highly recommend Hexcells and I shame myself for having taken so long to try it.  I have not been so tickled by puzzles like these since my old subscription to Games Magazine in the 90s.




Edit:  One small issue I should mention.  I could find no volume option other than to mute and the game was initially too loud for me.  If you're playing on Windows, right-click your volume on the taskbar and use the Volume Mixer, and this is easily remedied.

20512225.review:
I don't understand why this game is rated overwhelmingly positive. It's extremely easy. In fact, the only level that presented any challenge was the next to last level. During the other 29 levels you can easily figure out which cells to break and which to mark. That one level that is a challenge is only a challenge in the sense that it is tedious. Since you can't figure out which cells to mark based on any clues given you have to guess.

In other words, the whole premise of the game is flawed. The game is painfully easy except one level which plays exactly like minesweeper. The puzzles are either too easy or require blind guessing, neither of which are fun to me. I got 3 levels into the sequel before quitting. If I wanted to play minesweeper, I'd play minesweeper.

20511903.review: Havent felt more educated in my entire life.

20509364.review:
Inspired by minesweeper I was pretty hopeful given all of the positive reviews. In playing it, I was pretty underwhelmed. What I loved in minesweeper when I was younger was the sense of victory when you finally cleared a game. You'd have this whole hard level to get through, you'd start small, the tension would rise as you get further and further, and eventually you win and feel great. In Hexcells there was no sense of victory. You play a level, you screw up a couple times, and then you finish it and move to the next one.

I'll probably play a bit more. Maybe I will like it as the levels get more interesting, as it is though I was not overly impressed. As it is, if you want a calm puzzle game then it's probably worth it. If you want a modern day minesweeper I would not recommend it.

20403740.review:
As a player who decides what games to buy based on the reviews of the certain game, it's my duty to write a complete review about any game i finish, so here is my review:

HEXCELLS:

Hexcells is a puzzle game, where you must find out using logic if a certain cell is blue or not, depending on the information you are given about the cell. Yeah, not much to say about this one, only taht it's a really good game about puzzle lovers who like a really good challenge.

Before i procceed with the PROS and CONS i would like to remind anyone who is reading this that these are my personal preferences and may differ by any individual who plays the game.

PROS:
+Well designed puzzles.
+Helps against alzheimer (that's serious, it really helps your memory).
+Difficulty has a good scaling from one level to another.

CONS:

20391667.review:
Note: This review is for both Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite, because they're basically a single game divided in three parts.

The Hexcell games are a series of brilliant crafted puzzles that at first glance may seem like a six-sided minesweeper, but the logic used to solve them is closer to sudoku. As you progress through the levels, you are also introduced to some new mechanics accompained by a tutorial level to make sure that you understand them. Because the puzzles are carefully and wonderfully designed, you never have to guess your next move, but finding it gets hard in the later puzzles. The interface is clean and the sound effects are cool. Hexcells is easy, Hexcells Plus gets harder in the second half and Hexcells Infinite steps back a little at the beginning, but in the end offers the most challenging puzzles. It also comes with a seed-based puzzle generator, adding 999,999,999 additional puzzles (even if they aren't hand crafted, they're still good). My recommendation is that you get and play all three games in order, but if you can only pick one, pick Hexcells Infinite, it's main levels difficulty is nicely spread not to mention the puzzle generator.

Очень увлекательная головоломка, которая помогла мне скоротать время на некоторых скучных лекциях. Сначала использовал ее как возможность убить время, но потом она меня изрядно затянула и я продолжил играть в нее уже дома.
Эта игрушка - смесь сапера и судоку. С каждым "миром" загадки усложняются, добавляются новые элементы загадок, что добавляет еще больше интереса в эту игру. Тут, в отличие от сапера, нет элемента случайности - все поля тщательно продуманы и от вас требуется только напрячь свой мозг, чтобы решить загадку. Чем она сложнее - тем слаще вкус победы.  Но иногда приходится делать что-то наугад, когда кажется, что зашел в тупик и не можешь найти дальнейшее решение. В случае ошибки стараешься начать сначала и пройтись по всему еще раз, чтобы найти то, что сначала не смог. Старался решать все идеально с первого раза, ради ачивки. Над некоторыми последними пазлами приходилось ломать голову по полчаса. Но нисколько не пожалел о потраченном на эту игру времени.

20348630.review:
Logik- und Puzzlespiele frustrieren mich ja meistens nach einer Weile, da sie mir einfach zu schwer werden. Die ersten Level bekomme ich meistens noch ziemlich gut hin, aber irgendwann gebe ich auf und fühle mich dumm. Als ich beim Durchklicken meiner Steam-Empfehlungen Hexcells vorgesetzt bekam, wollte ich zunächst einfach weiterklicken, als mir die äußerst positiven Nutzerreviews ins Auge fielen. Da es außerdem im Angebot war, wagte ich einen Versuch.

Das Prinzip ist eigentlich ganz einfach: In einem vorgegebenen Wabengitter muss ein Muster aufgedeckt werden. Dies geschieht mit Hilfe von vorgegebenen Zahlen, die einem anzeigen, wie viele Waben in der unmittelbaren Umgebung (und später auch in einer Reihe) markiert werden müssen. Ausgeschlossene Waben kann man „zerstören“ und so neue Zahlen sichtbar machen. Der Trailer unten erklärt das Prinzip noch etwas besser dank visueller Unterstützung.

So arbeitet man sich nach und nach weiter vor und löst die Rätsel. In späteren Levels muss man dann schon geschickter kombinieren, um zu den Lösungen zu kommen. Dabei wird es nie zu schwer oder unfair, außerdem verändern sich die Rätsel nicht, sodass man einen Fehler eigentlich nie zweimal macht. So kommt wirklich jeder irgendwann zur Lösung. Ziel ist es natürlich, alle Level perfekt und ohne Fehler zu meistern, denn je weniger Fehler man macht, umso mehr Punkte erhält man, mit denen weitere Puzzle freigeschaltet werden.

Eigentlich kann ich nur einen wirklichen Kritikpunkt an dem Spiel äußern und das ist der Umfang. Man ist wirklich schnell durch. Wer mehr möchte, muss sich „Hexcells Plus“ und/oder „Hexcells Infinite“ kaufen. Beide habe ich aber noch nicht getestet.

Fazit: Hexcells ist ein gelungenes Puzzlespiel für Zwischendurch, das nicht zu schwer ist und über seine gesamte, wenn auch kurze Spieldauer viel Spaß macht. Da es nicht allzu viel kostet (bei Steam etwas mehr als auf der Herstellerwebseite aufgrund des Umrechnungskurses, aber manchmal hat man im Sale Glück und es kostet nur 0,99 €), kann ich eine klare Empfehlung aussprechen.

Wertung: 7,5 / 10

20276142.review:
80 minutes to get 98%. Recommended for fans of Minesweeper/Picross, at the price that you feel is appropriate for about 1.5 hours of play.

I have a fair amount of experience with Minesweeper and Picross-style puzzles, so this felt straightforward and fun. Hexcells ends up using the same logic you'd use for those games. All puzzles are 100% prove-able; there's no forced guessing between multiple spaces. I didn't notice anywhere that I had to string together much "if this, then this, then this, no that won't work"...no giant cascading logic messes. Comfortable and casual all the way through.

Some cautions:
 -- Unlike some similar games, you aren't marking tiles in a toggle-able way. That is, once you left- or right-click on a tile, it will immediately be shown to be correct or incorrect (which costs you a mistake).
 -- To me, the default left and right click felt backwards. I restarted the game and swapped them in the pre-game settings window with no problem.
 -- I played through almost the entire game in a windowed smaller resolution. Puzzle 29 did not fit entirely in the window, and I couldn't find any way to scroll or scale so I could see the whole puzzle. I had to exit back out and start again with non-windowed 1080p, since I figured that would be safe for all puzzles.
 -- The level select screen does not seem to indicate which puzzles you used a "mistake" on, so it looks like it would be annoying to go back and figure that out after the fact. I'd recommend that you immediately retry puzzles if you're aiming for the (very obtainable) perfect achievement, or at least write down which puzzles you'd need to retry later.

Don't get me wrong, these cautions are all very minor. I enjoyed this quick game.

六角形になっただけのマインスイーパと思わせて、途中からお絵かきロジック(いわゆるピクロス)っぽい要素も入る純粋なパズルゲーム。
三部作の第一作だけあって入門に最適な難易度となっているが、後半の方では頭をひねってどこから攻略するか悩むこともある面々が待ち受けている。
パソコン付属の一人用ゲームや○○○○ロジックにハマった人であればこのゲームにもハマるだろう。
面の数は少なめだがPlusやInfiniteをプレイする前準備にどうぞ。

以下ちょっとしたアドバイス
●初期設定では左クリックで青Hexをマーク・右クリックでHexを開けるといった具合にマインスイーパと逆になっているので、起動する前の設定画面で左クリックと右クリックの設定を逆にするとよい。
●言語依存度はかなり低いが、念のためにルールを以下にまとめる。
・黒Hexの数字：周囲1マスにある青Hexの数
・外の数字：ライン上にある青Hexの数
　(左クリックするとラインが明示され、右クリックすると灰色になって「青Hexを全てマークした」ことが示せる)
・{x}：x個の青Hexが途切れず黒Hexの周囲1マス/ライン上にある
　(ライン上のHexとHexに空白がある場合も、その間に別のHexが無ければ隣接しているとする)
・-x-：x個の青Hexが黒Hexの周囲1マス/ライン上にあるが一続きにはなっていない
　({x}のような配置でなければいい)
・マインスイーパと違い、黒Hexが隠れた所を青Hexとしてマークしようとしてもミスになる
●全ての面は理詰めで0ミスクリア可能。

20120411.review:
This game is simply great. If you are one of those cool people who pass their idle time on their PC by playing the classic minesweeper game, Hexcells takes that to a whole new level. 

Things I like about the game:
+ I bought all the three games (not costly at all) and it is absolutely fun.
+ The levels are totally solvable by logic and you wont face a guessing situation like you would in classic minesweeper game. This requires a lot more logical reasoning than minesweeper and I really loved it.
+ This game has its own ambient music (which some of you may like).
+ The display is clean and the game gives proper introduction on every new rule as they appear. 
+ The game runs equally smoothly on Linux, Windows and Mac. So I am able to play on different machines at work, or home.
+ Very small installation size, Downloads the game in a new machine instantly.
+ This game even has steam achievements.

Things I did not like about the game:
- No profile synchronization among devices. Everytime you install this in a new machine, you have to start from the beginning.
- Music could be a bit more mild, I did not like short length repeatative music, had it turned off within first few levels.
- Levels do not change, you can make mistakes and repeat the level with 0 mistake. Although if you challenge yourself honestly, this is not much of a problem (In the Infinity version, there are random levels though).
- I am not sure about the scoring system. How making mistake affects your score and if there is any relation with time etc.
- Short gameplay duration (this wont take you very long to complete, but I personally wont mind replaying).

So far, I like the game and would recommend to anyone who is into these type of tiny games.

Reasons:
1. The games is quite short but the price is even lower. Even though it took me around 2 hours, it is still the best money I've spent the last decade.

2. The design isn't fancy by any stretch of the imagination, but it's clean and easy to get a good overview.

3. The simplicity of the game combined with the progression to the more challenging puzzles makes it so that EVERYONE can play it and have a good time. I would guess the only difference would be the time.

4. The simple design makes it so that I think all of todays computer can run it. I would be surprised if my five year old phone couldn't run it. It is simple, clean and wonderfull!

20106854.review:
本游戏是一款画面简洁精美、设计思路明晰易懂的六边形扫雷类益智游戏，我是在2015年的圣诞特卖入的，本意是在各种刷刷刷中换个口味休闲一下，但却一发不可收拾的通了关，通关之后意犹未尽，思前想后，决定还是在这里推荐一下。

优点：
+所有方块内容都不需要猜，全都能靠已有提示内容推出来。
+画面很干净，音乐不烦人，与游戏主旨十分切合。
+非常容易全成就，而且成就图标泛用度高（当然，容易全成就也意味着，不耐玩……）

缺点：
-游戏流程过短，仅需1-2小时即可全部完成，据说在后两部中有所改观，但后两部我还没打（所以强烈推荐10块钱入一套三部曲而不是拆开单买，不过相信也没人会这样做）。
-与扫雷类游戏操作相反，需要在进入游戏之前的设置画面手动修改，这其实也算不得缺点，因为谁也没规定就一定是要左键打开右键标记，但怎么说呢，喜欢这类游戏的人多半是从扫雷过来的，因此统一操作其实还是很有必要的。
-部分新内容初次出现无提示，4-5关出现的“-x-”这种方块内部标志无定义提示，会导致玩家误认为是之前出现的其他类别标志而产生标示错误。可能是作者的遗漏，当然，瑕不掩瑜（也可能是我看漏了，不过返回去又找了一遍的确是没有找到对应提示）。

综上，可以确定，本作对于热爱扫雷游戏乃至热爱所有益智类游戏的玩家来说，十分值得推荐，十块钱你买不了吃亏，十块钱你买不了上当，是时候在打折期间入一套了！

提交于2015年12月30日16点20分，UTC+8。

20104041.review:
Hexcells is a logic puzzle game with a really simple concept: fill in all of the hexes on the screen. You do this by looking at the clues already given to you in the form of numbers and arrangements. For example, if you have a hex that has a number 2 inside it, that means 2 of the neighboring hexes will be blank blue ones and the rest will be other numbered ones. As you go through the different combinations and solve more of the puzzle, more clues and patterns will become apparent to you, until you're able to fill up everything.

The strategy is simple and intuitive, with easy to understand instructions whenever a new rule is added, so you never feel like you don't know what you're doing. It's very satisfying when you solve a super complicated puzzle and see how it all fits together like an equation. There were a couple of times when I felt like I wasn't given as many clues as was necessary and just had to guess, which is annoying, but these times were few and might have been simply my own incompetence.

The graphic scheme is obviously very bare-bones but it's very visually eye-catching, in my opinion, which is nice. There are only a couple of music tracks but they're very serene and help get you into the mood while you're puzzle solving.

Overall I think Hexcells is a pretty good game, challenging but not frustrating, and one that will give you a good 3-6 hours of play-time, and for that price it's definitely worth it. If you're a puzzle fan, I urge you to check it out.

20072259.review:
Some games have difficulty curves, but this has a difficulty wall. It occurs on World 6 (Level 24) and makes what would otherwise been a very easy game rather challenging. The puzzles do not seem to regenerate themselves after you quit a level which makes be believe the levels were designed by trial and error rather than algorithmically. If they did it algorithmically there could be an infinite amount of puzzles with different criteria matching to difficulty levels like you would see in Sudoku or nonograms/Picross which would add for potentially infinite replayability (and a fun Android game).

Some other gripes: the annoying music and the difficult to read "MENU" text in the top right. I actually quit the game and started it up again when I made mistakes since I didn't see that I could just return to menu. You'd intuitively think that "Escape" would allow you to go back to the menu after a confirmation but it doesn't do that. Sacrificing functionality for minimalism is indicative of the worse aspects of this trend towards minimal design.

In short, this game is like a cross between Minesweeper and Picross with incredibly easy levels except the last world which I am trying to 100% as I write this. Decent game all in all.

One negative is that puzzles can’t be saved mid game, so you lose progress when you exit.

Even though it can be quite quick to get through the 30 available puzzles I still recommend Hexcells as; one on sale it is very cheap, and two it’s a good starting point to ease you into the series. 

I had no technical issues with Hexcells.

19930570.review:
Hexcells plays like Minesweeper, using hexagons instead of squares. However, unlike Minesweeper which is randomly generated, each level in Hexcells is pre-made by the developer to have a unique and deducible solution. There are bits of spacial thinking that come in play, from crossword puzzles like Sudoku.

Hexcells also takes the minesweeper playstyle and increases the complexity (always offering a deducible solution though), by introducing row/column markings in lieu of additional viewable pieces, as well as special tile number markings that denote certain behavior of where the blue pieces will be.

I was a bit skeptical at first, but I'm really enjoying this series. I'm not noticing a terribly large complexity in this game, but I haven't gotten to the other two Hexcells games yet. I would recommend to people who enjoy puzzles.

19929002.review:
Ok, for a seemingly simple looking puzzle game, this one is surprisingly addictive.  It feels kind of like minesweeper, but with different ways of visualizing the pattern instead of just the number of "mines" surrounding a block.  Best of all, I have not had to guess once yet and I have beaten Hexcells, and am halfway through Hexcells Plus.  It does get challenging, but the solution can still be figured out using logic.  My wife even enjoys this game quite a bit, and she doesn't play games often.  

My main gripe with this game is that the controls feel backwards from minesweeper in that you left click the block that is part of the pattern (a mine), and right click an empty block.  I have played a good bit of minesweeper in the past and right click for mine and left click for empty was a very hard habit to break.  I had to restart many puzzles due to click confusion.  Unfortunately the game doesn't make you restart when you make a mistake, but it does keep track of the number of mistakes.  If you want to go for the perfectionist achievement, you have to beat every level without mistakes, and it doesn't seem to tell you which levels you made mistakes on if you choose to complete the stage with mistakes.  I get around this problem by restarting the level when I make a mistake.

Overall, this is a great addition to the library!

19828397.review:
Занимательная головоломка, отлично подходит для смены обстановки, когда любимые пасьянсы/кроссворды и т.п. уже натерли мозоли в глазах. Больше всего игра похожа на сапёра. Все правила постепенно объясняются на разных уровнях, понять их можно даже интуитивно (если комментария на англ. яз. будет не достаточно). Пока вы наслаждаетесь игрой звучит приятная мелодия, а само гексо-поле в начале напоминает медовые соты, такая сладкая получается ассоциация..

Больше всего в Hexcells порадовала большая вариативность условий. Это не просто определенное количество "заминированных" клеток - они, например, могут стоять подряд или могут быть разделены. Сложность такая, что позволяет именно получить удовольствие от процесса, а не сломать голову. 
Ещё один плюс: поле не "взорвется", когда вы "наступите на мину". Вам просто учтут ошибку (что, кажется не фатально, ведь уровень можно пройти снова). Так что путать кнопки на мышке теперь не страшно (а тут они противоположны саперу, что приятно заставляет мозг потрудиться привыкая к этому). Но в то же время это немного упрощает игру - поскольку мы выбираем из двух вариантов, если не ошиблись, значит правильный ответ известен. Но такие промашки скорее подстегивают начать сначала и разгадать всё без такой скрытой помощи.

Если говорить о минусах, то показалось (именно показалось), что есть моменты, когда нужно просто угадать в какой из двух клеток "мина". Это проблема жутко раздражала в сапере, но он вроде генерирует всё случайно, а тут продуманное поле. Очень надеюсь, что это не так. А пока играю дальше, потому что всё равно здорово!

10 гексов из 10 медовых сот

19737975.review:
I love this game. Hexcells takes the classic game of Minesweeper and pushes it to a whole new level. Instead of squares, you get hexagons - this sounds more difficult, and some of the levels are pretty challenging, but it was a great improvement. There's no guessing, either; you're always given just enough information to complete the level with zero mistakes. You can listen to the ambient, relaxing music as you test your brain with these 36 levels.

Not only are there numbers on the hexes, but once you get far enough there are also line headers (numbers above rows or beside columns) as well as counters on some of the blue tiles that tell you how many blue hexes are within the highlighted area. I think this game is unique, intuitive and overall very satisfactory. I got it on sale for less than a dollar, but I would have purchased it at full price. It's worth it.

If you're looking to test your puzzle solving skills, this game (and the entire series) is something to try out.

19722148.review:
[h1][b]Game Series[/b][/h1]

Hexcells is the first game of its' series.

[h1][b]Game Visual/Audio[/b][/h1]

There isn't much can be said about the game's visuals asides from that they're minimalistic. Pretty much the same thing can be said about the game's audio. 

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]

There is no difficulty mode option that's assigned. But each of the puzzles has their own difficult.

Hexcells is closely similar to mine sweeper game. So the objective is rather simple to figure out which cells to make blue and which cells to make black.

There are total of three slots with six world that has twenty-four puzzles to solve. The first world for each of the three slots are automatically unlocked. Completing one world will unlocked the next one. All of these puzzles can be replayed after the first go around. Please do note that the puzzles in the other two slots are the same as the ones in the first slot.

There's no time limit in this game. Allowing the individual take as much time that they want to solve each of the puzzles.

There six achievements for this game. Each of these achievements has certain requirements before they can be unlocked.

[h1][b]Miscellaneous[/b][/h1]

Final thoughts, it's an neat game to play and enjoy. As for the game's replay value it's low. I would recommend this game but not at the full price.

19681123.review:
"Hexcells" nimmt das altbekannte Minesweeper-Prinzip, erweitert es um ein paar Informationsangaben und ersetzt die Quadrate durch Hexfelder. Ach ja, und im Gegensatz zum Vorbild kostet einem ein Fehltritt nicht gleich das Leben, sondern man verliert nur einen Punkt in der abschliessenden Levelbewertung.

Kurz zum Spielprinzip
Die Zahl in einem Hexfeld gibt an, wieviele der angrenzenden Hexfelder blau sind. Diese gilt es aufzudecken. Zusätzlich können außen Zahlen stehen, die anzeigen, wieviele blaue Felder auf der kompletten Linie sind. Und geschweifte Klammern {x} bzw. Minuszeichen -x- zeigen an, ob die entsprechende Anzahl an Feldern zusammenhängen müssen ... oder eben nicht.
Durch die Kombination der in dieser Form vorgegebenen Informationen muss der Spieler nun alle zunächst orangen Felder entweder als "blau" (linke Maustaste) oder "schwarz" (rechte Maustaste) markieren. Macht man einen Fehler passiert nichts, man merkt also sofort das die ursprüngliche Wahl falsch war. Wenn man aber seine grauen Zellen etwas anstrengt kommt man fehlerlos durch alle Levels, denn im Gegensatz zu Minesweeper gibt es keine Stelle, an der man nur durch raten weiterkommt.

Эта игра представляет собой комбинацию сапера и японских кроссвордов. Поначалу кажется, что она слишком уж простая, тем более, что можно совершать ошибки. Но если стараться играть без ошибок, то становится сложней и интересней. И, тем не менее, всё решатся в уме, без дополнительных записей (в японских кроссвордах порой не обойтись без дополнительных записей).

Похоже, что во всех уровнях гарантированно есть путь к решению без ошибок (в сапере иногда приходится щелкать наугад). Кстати, чтоб избежать их, нужна ещё и внимательность, помимо логики.
Но, к сожалению, уровни все созданы заранее, так что рано или поздно можно запомнить сложный уровень и пройти его на 100%. Такова плата за их продуманность.

Игра сопровождается приятной музыкой.

В друой части уже есть множество различных уровней, помимо основных.

A very elegant minesweeper logic game with no guessing involved.   The graphics, music and fonts have a very clean and refined feel.  

The puzzles are interesting and challenging without being frustrating.  
There are variations in clues, such as numbers outside of columns that give the  total number of pattern matches in that column and indicated whether the pattern matches are contiguous or broken.  
The early puzzles are very relaxing.  The later ones sometimes require a bit of care and there were a few points where I spent 5 minutes not able to see what I was missing but, as a person who claims no great brilliance, I never felt out of my depth and the game never made me feel stupid.
 
If this type of game holds any appeal for you then it is well worth the small price to play something  more sophisticated than your standard minesweeper freebie included with your OS.

19573972.review:
This is a fun program to use.

I would not call it a game. I would not call it a puzzle game. To cut it short, I would not call it a video game.

My point can be summarized as the following:

If my experience from a 'game' does not decrease with printing out a screenshot and try to solve it on the table with a pen, what is the point of purchasing a videogame for the mentioned experience? There are billions of good puzzle newspapers, magazines which are much cheaper (per puzzle basis), and most of those even includes more than one type of puzzles. 

What I am talking about? There is no save in the middle of a mission. So if u are bored with a specific puzzle, you must start from anew. Paper and pen solution is better in this case. There is no undo for moves. While it is a good exercise for mistakes and incentivize perfecting things, sometimes I just misclick and got a correct filling. Since I am a bit obsessive about doing things without any hints, I really try hard to ignore that extra hint in the aftermath of the mistake. Again. Pen and paper approach is still nicer. Ok, not pen, but a pencil would do the job. Music is not outstanding, it is not even a music, just ambience sound, mostly I muted the game and opened some music of my own. Pen and paper approach is not worse in this aspect as well. It has no options, no metagame, no seeing how long your other friends took for solving some different puzzle. It has no occulus rift support :)So again, pen and paper approach is not inferior.

To summarize my point, I am not declaring this program is not fun to use. It is. It is a good mixture of minesweeper and griddlers, and especially as a fan of griddlers I enjoyed my time solving the puzzles. But I would also enjoy my time with solving them from a newspaper. While I mostly enjoy minimalistic setups in puzzle games, this one was too extreme in that. I really cant point out what is the difference between this program (I am insisting on not calling it a game) and a published puzzle thingy except it lets u know when u did a mistake instantly. 

Since puzzles are much easier in this compared to Hexcells plus, having no save feature is not that devastating in this first title. It still is annoying though.

Needs much polish before I can call it a game. Since all of the puzzles have a unique solution, I dont think we need a programmed thing for this kind of puzzle even. 

TLDR: Did I enjoy using this program? Yes. But I also enjoy my time solving some sudokus, or griddlers online, and this one does not stand out that much from some best voted griddlers in https://www.griddlers.net. So I dont think paying for this is well legitimized, especially after considering its short gameplay time.

PS: Some of my points are taken care of in Hexcells Infinite, by saving feature, a few options, and infinite puzzles thingy. But since those changes are not retroactive, they are not relevant reviewing of this game.

PS2: Most of the ones who check out for hubs of older games are fans of it. That is why, a negative review for an old game will most likely be heavily downvoted, since the ones did not like the concept already will not wander around that much. So, take possible downvotes with a pint of salt.

19568555.review:
Ein absolut klasse Spiel! :)

Vom Prinzip her sehr stark an Minesweeper angelehnt, aber doch noch irgendwie deutlich trickreicher. Es macht super viel Spaß zu zocken und ich kann es im Sale (für 0,99 Cent) nur jedem ans Herz legen, es hat allerdings leider viel zu wenig Level :( Hat grade mal zwei Vorlesungen lang gehalten.

An dieser Stelle eine kleine Empfehlung meinerseits: Ich liebe diese Art von Rätselspielen, da man diese auch in Vorlesungen spielen, aber dennoch komplett zuhören kann. Grade bei Fächern, wo es eher um das Verständnis als absolutes Detailwissen geht, sehr zu empfehlen, steigert bei mir sogar die Konzentration, da es vor dem Da-Rein-Da-Raus-Problem schützt ;)

Zusammenfassung:
+ Idee
+ Spielmechanik
+ Grafik (im Rahmen der Möglichkeiten echt gut gelungen!)
+ Steuerung absolut intuitiv, zwei Tasten sollte jeder schaffen
+ Universitätskompatibel
+ Spaß 12/10 :) 
+ Hoher Suchtfaktor ...

- ... aber leider nur sehr wenig Level :(

Für den Normalpreis wäre letzteres wohl wirklich etwas dürftig, aber der Spaß macht zumindest den Preis wieder gut. Wer mehr Umfang möchte, muss die Nachfolgeteile kaufen, da ist man für alle Spiele aber schnell bei 15 Euro. Im Sale 1A und kompromisslose Empfehlung!

It's Minesweeper with some additional elements that change the way you have to think about the feild of play -- Nothing wrong with that.

But, in Minesweeper, when you hit a mine, you lose. Here, you have a mistakes counter and no easy way of resetting. So, if you screw up, it doesn't matter. I found myself getting more frustrated at the fact that I had to return to the menu, rather than simply hit a reset. There's an acheivement for getting through with no mistakes, but that didn't feel like it added much.

There are not an over abundance of levels, which is a shame, becasue it was fun enough to play. I saw in the news that thereis an editor to make fan levels. I'm sure it is a grab bag.

I would have loved to see an infinite or random level generator, but i'm sure that would be much more difficult than a standard minesweeper level generator, simply because of the new mechanics added.

全成就达成！
大包打三折的时候买的，算起来这一个《六角细胞》还不到三块钱……看好了这才是真·白菜价！

优：
+风格简洁，音乐空灵，教科书式的休闲小清新。
+玩法新颖又不失难度，别以为六个方向（比微软扫雷少两个方向）就简单了哦。同时关卡设置合理，难度循序渐进，前期易于上手（除非你英体教看不懂教程），后期略有挑战性。
+成就易得。六个成就里五个是无脑型，只要解锁五个小关就有（你们还好意思放置+1吗！），剩下一个是零错误通关（一共三个大关，通一个就行），并不难，想想微软扫雷出错直接重来呢。
+如其他评测所言，逻辑性极强，可以一点不猜纯靠推理通关。（很赞同某位“数独+扫雷”的说法）
+和《山》一样有即使不掉卡也想挂机当屏保的冲动……（然而我没有《山》

缺：
-游戏流程很短，我这个智硬（中间卡了一次关，微软扫雷中级刚进百秒）解全成就都只用了2.3小时。可重玩性有限，三个大关相似度极高，后来的《六角细胞Plus》和前作几乎没区别，到了第三作《六角细胞：无限》有999,999,999个随机关卡（废话要是人工的不得累死），才成为一款真正能和微软扫雷相提并论的游戏。
-你走清新平面风也就算了，“主菜单”和“退出”那么重要的按钮敢再做得透明些吗？敢吗？！都快通关了才知道可以不用ALT+F4退出啊！（为了成就每次点错就得重来的很麻烦啊……

总结：4.5/5。
Would sweep again.

19342848.review:
The best way I can think of to describe Hexcells is not as a puzzle game, but as a "meditation game" and a sort of mental massage.

The gameplay follows on from Minesweeper, you start with the same rules, identifying blue hexes by the non-blue hexes telling you the number of adjacent blues.  But new mechanics are introduced which pushes it toward the realm of Sudoku.  I never found it frustrating or confounding, because the rules are simple enough that you only have to look for the next step, not make crazy leaps of logic.  Also, while you don't get a full score for making several mistakes, each mistake you make at the same time serves as a hint and moves you closer to the solution (a nice parallel with positivity in real life!)

So the gameplay requires you to be active and logical mentally, but not so much that you can't relax or have to get stressed.  And the rest of the game with its simple visuals and procedural ambient soundtrack works to make one of the most relaxing experiences I've seen in games.  The puzzles and music are in a nice area between idleness and frustrating which lets you slip easily into a meditative state while playing.

I highly recommend this game, especially if you turn off the TV, turn the lights down a bit, kick up your feet, turn on a humidifier, lay a damp washcloth on your forehead, and just completely relax while playing.  For anyone dealing with excessive levels of stress or anxiety, this game could be outright therapeutic!

19322729.review:
I really don't understand the appeal. 

In this game, like minesweeper, you have to find the 'mines' with the number of adjacent mines of one tile. The difference are that few levels of Hexcell aren't randomly generated and more complex mechanics are introduced as you go on. 

The first problem I have with this game is that it does not let you fail. Rather than failing a level for hitting a 'mine', it only count your mistake. It sound like a good thing, but it simply inadvertently spoils the game. I admit that I don't know what could be done to fix this, but nevertheless its the equivalent to trying to solve a math problem with the answer in front of you. You might do your best not to look, you still end up figuring something that you wouldn't have normally.

The second problem is related to the few inconsistencies of the game. It's a minor issue, but sometimes, it seems that the game take liberties with its own rules (or simply doesn't set them). For example;

Two mines in a row of four tiles are said to be next to each other? Turn out that 'next to each other' still count when the row is separated by a huge white space.   

symbols like '--' indicate that mines aren't next to each other? It only mean that at least one mine is not connected to the others.

etc.

Like a said, this is a minor issue, but combined with a very short unpunishing game, it doesn't leave you anything worthwhile. I can't recommend this game when other interesting puzzle games are available for the same price.

19310702.review:
The board is almost solved with no mistakes so far. With numbers and blue cells everywhere, all that is left is two yellow cells. It's unclear what cell's to be cleared, and what cell is to be marked. You look at the board, squinting your eyes as you make hypotheses about what would happen if either cell was marked. 

And then, when you're as confident as an eagle swooping down for prey, you slowly but steadily bring your mouse cursor to the cell you chose. You're sure you can't be wrong; after all, you thought it all out. The numbers all add up. It's a calculated move. This cell just can't have a number below it.

And as the cursor finally lands on top of the cell, you click with your mouse. 

But it turns out you pressed RMB.

11/10. Super Meat Boy for intellectuals.

18885326.review:
Hexcells erinnert vom Spielprinzip etwas an ein stylish aufgemachtes "Minesweeper" aus alten Windows-Zeiten. Dabei gibt eine Zahl immer an, wie viele "gute" Felder in der jeweiligen Reihe oder den Nachbarfeldern enthalten sind. War das damals bei "Minesweeper" nur immer wieder ein Zufalls-Feld, das u.U. nicht lösbar war, so hat man es hier im Grunde mit leichten mathematischen Logikaufgaben zu tun. 
Alle Puzzles sind fehlerfrei lösbar und das fühlt sich natürlich viel besser, bzw. zielgerichteter an. Die Schwierigkeit nimmt nat. pro Runde zu, auch die Art der Angaben variiert und so entfalten die höheren Stufen durchaus eine Herausforderung für den Spieler, die aber immer noch Spaß macht.

Hexcells ist etwas für alle, die Puzzlespiele mögen und die weder Hektik noch Action brauchen. Eine ganz klare Empfehlung - und nach einiger Zeit mag man es evtl. sogar ein weiteres Mal gerne durchspielen.

18820374.review:
Hexcells is a delightful little puzzle game, a bit like minesweeper but much more interesting and well-built. Unlike Minesweeper, you never need to guess in Hexcells - using the hints provided at the beginning of the level, you can work your way to a completed field using logic alone. If you're a fan of sudoku or Minesweeper, I can guarantee you'll enjoy this game.

As the first game in the series, it lacks a bit of the polish of later entries (saving partially completed puzzles isn't added until the third installment) and it's a little to easy to get to the end (I got perfect on all stages in less than four hours taking my time), but it serves as a great introduction to the much more challenging later games. I reccomend picking up all three games on sale as I did - the difficulty scales is such a way that it feels like playing through one larger game.

Overall, a really refreshing, if somewhat easy, puzzle game. Grab the sequels if you want more polish and challenge.

18257573.review:
First, a warning: the menu screen of the game lists three "slots": Slot 1, Slot 2, Slot 3. These are not different parts of the game! I didn't figure it out at first so I finished the game three times without knowing it... Nowhere is stated that the 3 "slots" are identical. Bad design!

Other than that, well... This game is a lot similar to the absolute Microsoft classic, Minesweeper. Only cooler (and combined with the Japanese game of Kakuro). Main difference is that you almost never have to guess anything (mayber never, but it seems I didn't get all the hints). Which means you solve the puzzles like a math problem, using only logic. it feels great, but it also makes the game really easy. 

The game is also super short (don't let my playtime fool you, I actually left it running for a whole afternoon while I was out running errands) and contains only 30 puzzles; out of these 30, about 4 are actually challenging — there is more tutorial levels in the game than actual puzzles.

And one last thing, the music sounds nice at first but quickly becomes annoying, and you can't deactivate it while in game (again, bad design).

Bottom line: I had fun for about 20-30 min and thought the idea behind Hexcells was great, but the game is too easy and way too short for me to recommend it. It would have been free, I would have said go and play it! But I don't think it's worth 2,99 €. It's just like... a draft. 

I was enticed by the concept though so I'm gonna try Hexcells Plus and see if it is better. See you there.

18180240.review:
They should rename this game "The Science of Deduction".

Slow, deliberate deduction makes for the most satisfying puzzles because, unlike with most puzzles, the answer isn't found in guessing the designers intentions through trial and error. The answer comes solely from your ability to apply elementary logic. That's not to suggest this game is lacking in challenge. As it progresses, the elements of logic coalesce into molecules and you'll routinely need to retain and apply handfuls of algebraic deductions just to make a single correct move. If Sherlock Holmes played any one game, it'd be this one. I can't think of a game short of a Baldur's-Gate-2-caliber genre-definer that I would recommend more. The pleasure of gradually breaking through each puzzle is exquisite.

P.S. If you intend to look up hints/solutions like some (read: many) of the forum dwellers, simply give up on life instead.

I don't know, maybe there are people who play Steam games on their phones but I can't. Just ask yourself this if you aren't convinced: do you want to spend 4 bucks and spend a couple of hours playing a FINE game of Minesweeper? [b]Hexcells[/b] makes for a good logic puzzler, it's just... underwhelming. Heck, at least Minesweeper's levels are randomly generated; there's always a new experience for when you're bored. 18068805.review:
This is an easy recommendation to make! YES!

Hexcells is a puzzle game that's sort of like Minesweeper, but with more unique twists (many more rulings to make it a bit more complex). It's a frustrating game in the sense that you feel that you should be able to solve it, and making mistakes disappoints you more than you'd think (especially if you're after the Achievements - but even then, it keeps count how many mistakes you've made so far and displays it for the whole level, which stings). At some point, you'll likely get frustrated when you dont know what move to make - but you know that (and I can confirm that) there is always a 'legal' or 'smart' move (meaning it's assured correct; no need to have to guess to proceed). 

For those after the Achievements, this is a (relatively) quick game to go for - four hours and a bit for me to complete, counting restarts when mistakes are made (but I'm a puzzle afficionado so I might have ate through it a bit faster than average) and a noteworthy detail is that you dont feel like you're achievement hunting (as in doing obscure actions for the achievement) so much as just playing the game to its full.

At this price? It's an easy buy - but getting it on sale, more especially on the complete pack? 
The game is more than worth the price!

As an aside, even if the levels are the same, there is replayability in that the field is just so expansive and keeping track of all the minute details is near impossible.

Get this game! The developers did a really good job with it!

18065922.review: 这款游戏的游戏模式跟扫雷非常类似，然而跟扫雷不一样的是，扫雷经常是要靠运气猜才行，有的地方完全是靠推理解不出来的。这款游戏不一样，他的每一关都可以完全推理出来而不用靠运气去猜，因为扫雷是电脑随机生成的而这游戏每一关都是游戏作者精心设计出来的。然而一开始我发现这游戏的键位和扫雷完全是反着的，这游戏是左键点击有雷的地方，右键点击没雷的地方。玩儿了一段时间之后我才发现原来在进入游戏之前的那个input选项卡里可以进行改键设置。当时我的内心几乎是崩溃的，卧槽劳资刚适应新键位啊，但是重度强迫症的我又不得不改了键位重新适应，说多了都是泪啊。。。。。。。。。。。。。。。。。

18000136.review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [td]おすすめ度[/td]
        [td]★☆☆☆☆[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]難易度[/td]
        [td]★☆☆☆☆[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]日本語[/td]
        [td]なし[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]コントローラ[/td]
        [td]非対応[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]実績[/td]
        [td]簡単、3時間程度で全実績の解除が可能[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

マインスイーパとピクロスを掛けあわせたようなゲーム。

[h1]良かった点[/h1]

音楽や効果音がちょっと不思議な感じで良い。
マインスイーパと違い、必ずロジックだけでクリアできる。運に任せてマスを開かなければいけない、という状況が存在しない。
実績の解除が簡単。ミスを許容して進むかどうかにもよるが、3時間程度で全実績の解除が可能。
安い。セール時で100円を切る。

[h1]悪かった点[/h1]

全体的にインタフェースがイマイチ。特にマウスの左クリック/右クリックの役割がマインスイーパと逆なのはいただけない。自分だけかも知れないが、かなり頻繁に押し間違えた。
爆弾の位置が連続しているのか、離れているのかという表記があるが、その表示が似ているため、どちらがどちらかわかりにくく、見間違えることがしばしばある。

[h1]感想[/h1]

ボリュームは少ないが、値段が安いので相応だと思う。マインスイーパやピクロスのようなゲームが好きな人、もしくは実績目当ての人にはおすすめ。

This game is pretty (both in terms of its clean visuals and ambient soundtrack), fun, and offers zen-like satisfaction, but if you're into puzzle games I very much recommend buying it as part of the complete pack. This, the first game in the trilogy, is little more than a glorified tutorial, and only has one or two levels that pose any real challenge - I got 100% in three hours. Maybe you'd buy this game to find out if you want the other two, but spoiler: you do. The other two are where the meat of the game lives.

I'm going to recommend this, but with a caveat: I highly recommend this if you consider the whole trilogy as one game (it is very reasonably priced as "one game"), but I don't really recommend this title in isolation.

17891537.review:
Hexels is a nice puzzle game that plays on number and logic puzzles in a style that seems reminiscent of minesweeper, but on a hexagonl grid.

The puzzles themselves are for the most part solvable by logic. The only one that had me completely stumped as to how to start it was puzzle 6.2. This game is only worth getting if you want to exercise your understanding of logic, however. As the puzzles are not generated randomly, you could just look up the solutions online, or click randomly to beat them.

The music in this game is very nice, and is pretty "zen".

The graphics are very nice and minimalist, however there is a glaring bug in the game. When you hover over cells, they "wiggle". This is a nice addition, however sometimes the wiggle is enough to let you see what is underneath, which ruins the point of using logic. A solution to this is to use flux to remove the blue colour from your screen, but that is points against the game. If you don't have flux, try and avoid hovering over the cells to much.

The game only took me about 2 hours to complete, so it's fairly short, but if you want something to exercise logic, then this is a good game to play.

17831219.review:
Hexcells is a simple logic puzzle game. While it starts off very easy, it later on can get a bit more complicated, often taking me a while to "see" some clue I was missing.

I've had this on my library for a long time, and only recently have I decided to play it, after Kami.
This is more up my alley. The game can be very formulaic, perhaps, as there's never the need to "guess" any move. If you observe the board carefully, you'll have everything you need to make the next correct move. Initially, I didn't think it was that good, most levels being rather short and obvious. Thankfully, things got more complicated, levels bigger, and the game proved very satisfactory!

It's very similar to minesweeper, although there's no losing. You won't touch a bomb and restart. Instead, you'll have +1 mistake, that later affects how many gems you get, for completionists' sake.
The game also has various sets of puzzles, introducing a new mechanic between each one, keeping things interesting, without overwhelming the player with everything at once.


Puzzle-wise, it's alright. I enjoyed it, but it's nothing mind blowing, in my opinion.

What makes it stand out, for me, is the audio design. It's amazing! It's very minimalist, but it works really well!
With most puzzle games, I just have my own music on... in the case o Hexcells, it felt rather out of place. There's an ambient track constantly playing in the background, but your actions in the game produce sound-effects in sync with the background track and create a great sense of "atmosphere", even in a puzzle game!

It's something I rarely see in videogames that aren't music related. They tend to ignore how sound and music is important, so Hexcells is a breath of fresh air, to me!

For that reason, above all else, I'll recommend this game. Looking at the developer's games, it seems indeed that sound always plays an important role, so I'll definitely be looking out for me! 
Elegant is a good word to describe it, I'd say.

17230440.review:
I'm something of a Picross nut, having played and near-beaten most of Nintendo's Picross games. When I saw Hexcells on the Steam New Releases section, I was quite happy; I have always thought these kinds of logic puzzles were better on a platform with a mouse. A few bucks later (thanks to Steam trading card sales - this game doesn't give out cards, btw), I had Hexcells in my library.

The actual logic of Hexcells is not difficult to grasp. If you've played Minesweeper or Picross 3D, you'll be right at home. You'll be following numbers inside of hexes, with symbols indicating whether the surrounding blue hexes will be consecutive or split, and later you will find numbers on rows or columns as well, with similar symbols. These symbols are, admittedly, not as easy to remember as I'd like (a problem that even Picross 3D had). I've made a few mistakes in puzzles because I misread the symbol in a given hex. In a related note, it's also somewhat easy to forget which mouse button performs which function, causing stupid mistakes that get recorded in your level score. Hexcells does not have a time limit of any kind, so you are essentially free to brute-force your way through a puzzle if you so desire, but making mistakes reduces how many hexes you receive as a reward for that level, and Steam Achievement nuts will probably want to avoid doing that if possible, as there is an achievement awarded for getting a perfect score on every level.

Presentationally speaking, Hexcells is simple and pleasing. The visuals are extremely minimalist (hexagons, and only hexagons); the only visual effects you'll be seeing are the tiny animations for shading or breaking hexes. The music is electronic ambience, in the style of Solar Fields (i.e. Mirror's Edge or Capsized), with the added effect that in-game sound effects are played on rhythm, a la Lumines or Rez. If I could complain about the presentation in any area, though, Hexcells does not provide a color-blind option (though I am not color-blind, I am unsure if the game's use of blue and orange would cause problems for those who are), and the low-contrast nature of the backgrounds makes the "Menu" button difficult to find.

I am pleased to report that Hexcells performs admirably on both Windows and Linux, owing to its nature as a Unity game. I would presume that Macintosh support is also good, as a result. Both of my test machines (no slouches, admittedly) ran the game with no obvious slowdowns or graphical glitches. I'd wager most machines made in the last half-decade will work just fine; I suppose netbooks may be feasible as well, but as I do not have access to one right now, I cannot say for certain, so Your Mileage May Vary.

About the biggest complaint I have about Hexcells, though, is that there are just not enough puzzles. Hexcells offers 6 "worlds," with five puzzles each, and the last puzzle essentially acting as a credits reel. I finished the game in a little over an hour, though I have not achieved Perfect on every puzzle just yet.

All that said, though, at $3 or less, Hexcells is certainly not a waste of your money. I'd like to see more logic-puzzle games like this on Steam.

16755341.review:
Hexcells is one of the best puzzle game experiences I've had.

It starts off with a simple Minesweeper-like premise. After a few levels, the game begins its brilliance by adding new types of clues beyond "three of the surrounding hexes are empty," turning the game into something resembling a nonogram-like puzzle (the kind of puzzle featured in Nintendo's Picross games). These mechanics are backed up by excellent puzzle design and an ambient soundtrack that keeps players relaxed and focused as they work their way through the puzzles.

The only serious flaw in the game is that there isn't any replay value. There is still quite a bit of skill in repeating the large puzzles without making a mistake, but gradually players will remember the patterns and can cheat by learning from previous mistakes. Smaller puzzles also suffer as they can become simple exercises in trial and error.

Yet that flaw is a minor complaint. Anyone who enjoys logic-based puzzles should give this one a go. After finishing it, check out Hexcells Plus for an even greater challenge or Hexcells Infinite for an endless amount of content.

新式扫雷，我爱这种需要绞尽脑汁去思考的游戏。
合理的逻辑，舒缓的音乐，随着正确点击产生的音效，组合起来是让人放松地去开动大脑，却不容易让人产生焦躁的心理。
先前单看游戏理念就一口气买了本体 ，plus和infinite，相对比以后觉得，虽然这是一个老的版本，在游戏过程中的人性化相对新版本来说没有这么舒服，但是谜题部分相当值得重复游玩。
除了扫雷的基础模式，还添加了新的逻辑规则。游戏在教授新的规则时并没有用过多的文字描述，设立一个必须使用此规则的简单关卡来告诉玩家如何游玩这一点非常良心，至少我本人就非常喜欢这种模式的教学。
虽然老版本没有设立云备份，但是三个记录存档非常便利。我完全可以在一个新的记录存档里面再重新思考一遍谜题——全部的关卡值得反复琢磨至少三次，更何况游戏音乐本身就值得沉浸在这个解密的过程中。
经典谜题是值得人们反复去解密的。
当然不知道能不能将infinite中的技术反过来更新一下这个版本，个人对于蓝色方块的提示显示方式，认为显示线条边框的显示方式更人性化一些。

【簡単なルール説明】
数字は周りの爆弾の数
左クリックで爆弾確定。右クリックで空白確定
{○}はその数だけ連続した爆弾がある
-○-はその数の爆弾があるが、全部は連続していない
枠外の数字はその縦列（or斜め）の爆弾の数。数字をクリックすれば対象の列に線が通ります。
枠外の{○}や-○-は空白地も続いていると考えること

16518285.review:
Pros:
- Based on classic Minesweeper, but more forgiving
- All levels are solvable without guessing - lots of satisfaction when you complete one!
- Nice atmosphere, albeit maybe distracting

Cons:
- Becomes rather bland after a while
- Quite short

I find Hexcells cute - it's basically an interesting iteration on classic Minesweeper. The basic mechanics are pretty much the same, the difference being that squares are now hexagons. It's also a lot more forgiving, although you'll likely find yourself restarting games just because you want to complete each level without any mistakes. Besides, all levels are solvable without guessing, and  completing a difficult level will often fill you with satisfaction. The atmosphere is quite enjoyable, although I found myself switching off the sound because it could be slightly distracting.

However, there is some criticism to be made. Once you get the grip of the game mechanics, which should happen quite soon, the game becomes rather limited. The most challenging levels become a time for staring at the screen, wondering "what am I missing?". You'll often get stuck and resort to carefully scanning the screen, trying to find out which is the next tile you can click on. And that is why I'd game this game a mixed review if I could - it can become a test of patience rather than one of cleverness. Although fans of Minesweeper will not probably be bothered much. ;) 

The game is also quite short, considering that I beat all levels with a perfect score in just two hours. However, if you can get this one in a bundle or in an offer (I got it for 0.89 Euro), then it's likely that you'll have put your money to good use.

16511045.review: Minesweeper, but way better.  This is my ultimate relaxation therapy.  The simple tones and self-pace are perfect for a chill noodling session.  You can logic your way through every puzzle, there are no 50/50 decision points.  The difficulty progression is steady and perfectly appropriate.  I love the use of new deduction indicators.  I highly recommend, and the Hexcells: Infinite, with a random board generator, will stay in my favorites for a long time to come.

Hexcells is Minesweeper if Minesweeper used hexagons instead of squares and had minor aspirations towards being Sudoku. Probably the biggest differences between Minesweeper and Hexcells are that Hexcells starts with a number of tiles uncovered so that you don't have to make the initial random clicks to get onto the board; Hexcells doesn't fail you outright for making a mistake or two; and Hexcell only comes with a limited number of set levels rather than randomly generating them.

It's a basic time waster that only takes a couple of hours or so to complete. I only really purchased it because it was on sale and even then I'm not sure that I couldn't have done better... 16366081.review:
I really enjoyed my time with [b]Hexcells[/b], it's a simple but very challenging puzzle game that can keep you entertained for hours. It's often refered to as a twist on the old game called Minesweeper, and in a sense it is fairly similar, but more challenging and definitely much more satisfying to play with it's ambient theme and elegant graphics style.

The rules are simple enough to understand after the first few puzzles, with some more rules and features being introduced as you progress. Clear the orange hexes to reveal the patterns underneath, numbers indicate the amount of surrounded hexes that are part of the pattern. Complete each of the puzzles making as few mistakes as possible so that you can progress through to the next set.  

There isn't much more to say about this game other than the fact that it is brilliant. [b]Hexcells[/b] is one of the best puzzle games I have played in recent years and I am really glad that I picked it up in the Steam Sale to give it a try, for such a cheap price, it's more than worth it. Would definitely recommend this to any puzzle fans of any age.

The game does give you instructions on what some things mean from time to time, and guides you throughout the game when you reach something new. Overall, this is a point and click game, no keyboard needed.

Artwork:
Gorgeous. It’s uniform throughout, there are no random changes. It’s no da Vinci, but it’s still very well done. If I absolutely HAD to complain, I’d say that the patterns on the levels aren’t the prettiest, but this game is a puzzle game, not an art game.

Music/sound:
Nothing caught my attention, but everything was constant throughout.

Storyline:
Not applicable to this game. Just advance through all 6 levels!

End Impression:
I loved this game so much that I played and completed it in 3 hours. I also loved it to the point where I had to complete each level perfectly, no mistakes allowed.

Parting Words:
If you love minesweeper, get this game. The complete pack (3 games in one) is on sale for $2.69 until June 22, and in my opinion very much worth. (I got gifted the $0.89 one)

SCORES:
Gameplay: 10/10
Artwork: 10/10
Music/Sound: 6/10
Storyline: N/A

Overall score: 9/10

If you had one of the older Microsoft Windows versions, than you might remember the game Minesweeper. You had to find the mines and avoid them by marking them. It worked with some clues, since numbers gave away how many mines are close by.

15914854.review:
Deduction and puzzle game lover, here's a perfect game [i]series[/i] for you!

Hexcells is the first one of the series. In Hexcells the game area consists of hexes, each having zero to six neighbours. Hex is either blue or black with a number. Mechanics familiar from Mine Sweeper (MS), the number states how many blue hexes are next to the black hex. Your job is to reveal for all hexes whether they are blue or black.

Unlike in traditional MS, everything can be deduced - guessing is not required at all if you know what you are doing. The controls are similar to MS, with left- and right-clicking determining whether you think the hex is blue or black one. Also, in case of a mistake you don't need to start at the beginning, though if you do more than one mistake, you have to start again if you want a "perfect" score (and ultimately an achievement).

The learning curve is very smooth, the challenge rising gently towards later, larger puzzles. As you get further, new mechanics are introduced, with similarities to nonograms/hanjies: a number will state that a column or a diagonal will have certain number of blue hexes. There are two special cases to this that either say that all blue hexes will be interconnected or that they must have a break in-between. All mechanics naturally introduce new ways to think and deduce through the puzzles.

Music is ambience like "glowing crystals", and when you make right moves there's a distinct "ding!" sound echo that adds fluidly to the ambience.

All the 36 puzzles are well-designed and fairly interesting. This is also its biggest drawback: there is little replay value after beating all the puzzles, a task that takes just a couple of hours. The other drawback is the lack of a save feature (for single puzzles; game obviously remembers if you have beat a puzzle before), so you have to complete each puzzle fully or either leave the game running or start the level again later. If these features are a bottleneck for you, both of them [i]are[/i] introduced in [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/304410/]Hexcells Infinite[/url], the third part of the series.

If you're left craving for more, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/271900/]Hexcells Plus[/url] is the de-facto sequel. You should really play Hexcells first and only then go to Plus though, for the sequel is way more challenging and introduces all the mechanics from early on and even adds one new one. [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/304410/]Hexcells Infinite[/url] is a good alternative to both: it has its own puzzles and all the mechanics and features from Hexcells and Hexcells Plus, but the challenge curve starts from easy like Hexcells and goes to difficult like Plus. In that respect it's more stand-alone than Plus sequel.

All three are nevertheless good puzzle games. As for challenge, Hexcells is the easiest one and therefore the natural place to start. Also, it's a fairly cheap investment.

15655971.review:
Hexcells est un mini-jeu de réflexion, du même type qu'un Démineur : la principale différence tient du fait que le joueur n'a pas affaire à des carrés (4-voisins), mais à des hexagones (6-voisins).

2 touches sont disponibles : un clic et l'on colore une case (mine), l'autre clic et l'on découvre la case, c'est-à-dire le nombre de cases piégées voisines. Simplissime.

Au gré des niveaux, quelques variations apparaissent : indications sur le nombre de cases piégées le long d'une ligne entière ou dans une zone de 2 cases de rayon, et leur contiguïté (ou leur discontinuité). Ces variations apportent de nouvelles stratégies de grilles... qui peuvent commencer à demander un bon coup d'oeil. Point très positif : AUCUNE grille ne nécessite de faire des "coups au pif" pour avancer. Elles sont toutes très faisables.

Ce premier Hexcells se compose d'une unique campagne de 5 grandes étapes, qui se débloquent en gagnant des points à chaque niveau (points ramassés en faisant le moins d'erreurs possible).

Enfin, contrairement au jeu suivant, Hexcells Plus, les grilles restent toutes relativement simples et rapides à faire (Hexcells peut donc être considéré comme une introduction aux jeux suivants).

15488673.review:
[h1]Der Puzzle-Snack für zwischendurch[/h1]

[b]"Hexcells"[/b] nimmt das altbekannte Minesweeper-Prinzip, erweitert es um ein paar Informationsangaben und ersetzt die Quadrate durch Hexfelder. Ach ja, und im Gegensatz zum Vorbild kostet einem ein Fehltritt nicht gleich das Leben, sondern man verliert nur einen Punkt in der abschliessenden Levelbewertung.

[u]Kurz zum Spielprinzip[/u]
Die Zahl in einem Hexfeld gibt an, wieviele der angrenzenden Hexfelder blau sind. Diese gilt es aufzudecken. Zusätzlich können außen Zahlen stehen, die anzeigen, wieviele blaue Felder auf der kompletten Linie sind. Und geschweifte Klammern [b]{x}[/b] bzw. Minuszeichen [b]-x-[/b] zeigen an, ob die entsprechende Anzahl an Feldern zusammenhängen müssen ... oder eben nicht.
Durch die Kombination der in dieser Form vorgegebenen Informationen muss der Spieler nun alle zunächst orangen Felder entweder als "blau" (linke Maustaste) oder "schwarz" (rechte Maustaste) markieren. Macht man einen Fehler passiert nichts, man merkt also sofort das die ursprüngliche Wahl falsch war. Wenn man aber seine grauen Zellen etwas anstrengt kommt man fehlerlos durch alle Levels, denn im Gegensatz zu Minesweeper gibt es keine Stelle, an der man nur durch raten weiterkommt.

Insgesamt enthält das Spiel 36 Level, für die man im Durchschnitt immer nur ein paar Minütchen braucht ... also das ideale Spiel für die Mittagspause und der Preis von 3€ ist durchaus fair.

Hexcells is one of the best logical puzzle games on Steam. It has a nice clean look and has a no-nonsense approach... it gets you right into the puzzling and teaches you how to play with a very unintrusive "tutorial". Every puzzle can be beaten without hints, and the harder levels will really test your lateral thinking skills. For that matter, I can't think of any game on Steam that test your lateral thinking more than Hexcells, with the exception of the sequels which include more approaches to solving puzzles.

You cannot go wrong with the Hexcells games if you want some quality logical puzzlers.

P.S. If you really like Minesweeper and have played it for more than a few hours you're going to want to switch the keybinds in Hexcells since they are the opposite of Minesweeper (left click by default marks "mines" and right click clears safe spots). 15145861.review:
[b]What is Hexcells?[/b]
Hexcells is a puzzle game that looks rather like Minesweeper. Players are presented with an orange grid comprised to hexagons and it is up to them to determine whether these cells belong to the blue pattern or not (black cells). The black cells not part of the pattern have a number in them to indicate how many blue cells are adjacent to them, thus providing a clue as to how to proceed.
After completing a puzzle the player is awarded blue hexcells based on the amount of mistakes made; these in time accumulate to unlock one of five new areas - allowing you to complete more difficult puzzles. Some areas also introduce new clues and rules to help you, making the puzzles more complex over time. 

Although similar to Minesweeper as mentioned, there is a key difference: there is always a logical next step. You never have to take a gamble so if you feel stuck, take a step back and focus on another area.

[b]Why I recommend the game[/b]
Hexcells is a very simple puzzle game in its visual design. The menu is simple and provides the players with the option of turning the ambient music on or off and selecting one of three save slots. The same can be said for the puzzles themselves; a grid of hexagons on a white backdrop. To me this is good design, as I'm here for the puzzles and that's where the focus clearly lies.
The 30 puzzles themselves are interesting and there are enough additions in terms of new rules/clues during the course of a playthrough to keep them fresh and interesting. I just wish there were more.

However, this does not mean that the game is without flaws. For instance, it is not possible to erase a save slot so starting completely from scratch is not an option if all three slots are in use. Furthermore, the puzzles tend to be on the easy side, for me anyways.
My biggest problem with the game is that there is no option to save mid-puzzle forcing you to either finish it or redo the part you already completed next time.

All that being said, I've had a lot of fun playing this game and would recommend it as the pros outweigh the cons for me. I would encourage those interested in puzzle games to give this one a try.

15125232.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hg7rJmB0BFg&feature=youtu.be

Yesterday I had a headache, and was searching for a game that I could play to get my mind off of it. I wanted something without action, and I wanted to listen to some of my own relaxing music. I knew a puzzle game would be a perfect fit, and that's how I came across Hexcells. So I put on my music, and got right to the relaxing world of math.

Hexcells is a game where a bunch of hexagons come together, and you must figure out if the orange hexagons are blue, or a number. Sound simple sure, but how does one figure out this crazy math! Each puzzle starts off showing some numbered hexagons. This number is equal to the amount of blue hexagons that are touching it. So if it says four that means four blue hexagons are touching, and if it says zero then that means no blue ones are touching.

Let's stay with the zero example for a little bit. So if it says zero then you'll want to right click all the hexagons that are touching it. This gives you more options to play around with as it opens up more of the playing field. For another example lets move on to if the hexagon says one. Since this one already is touching a blue hexagon then you can right click on all the other hexagons touching this hexagon with the number one.

Hexcells was a great way to just kick back, and play a mindless game that actually requires some brainpower. Think of it like a Sudoku, or word search puzzle. You're using your brain, but it's not something you have to concentrate too hard on.

As Hexcells carried on it added more rules to it. One for example was having numbers at the top, or sides of the puzzle. When you see this number that's telling you how many blue hexagons are in that row. There's more to the world of Hexcells, but that's for you to find out about.

It took me a little over two hours to beat Hexcells, and I was kind of sad it was over so soon. I want more puzzles! I really enjoyed my time figuring out these puzzles, and think if you're a fan of Sudoku puzzles, or puzzles in general you'll enjoy Hexcells. Worth the price of $2.99, and worth your time.

15022287.review:
[i]Hexcells[/i] is a simple puzzle game along the lines of [i]Picross[/i], but with hex-shaped tiles. Unlike [i]Picross[/i], the patterns in [i]Hexcells[/i] are completely abstract. Numbers in the hex grid and along the edge give you hints as to which tiles are part of a pattern. Left-clicking on a tile will mark it as part of the pattern while right-clicking will remove the tile from the grid. Underneath removed tiles, numbers will appear that indicate the number of adjacent tiles that are part of the pattern. Numbers along the grid edge give you additional hints as to how many tiles are in an entire row. Numbers inside brackets indicate that the tiles are contiguous, while numbers inside dashes indicate the not all tiles are contiguous.

Successfully completing a pattern awards you with hexes based on the number of mistakes you made. A single mistake will not hinder you, but any additional errors will deduct from your awarded hexes. The first set of puzzles start out simple and feel more like training for the later ones. The last two worlds started to get more challenging and required much more use of logic instead of quick and obvious deduction. I bet that [i]Hexcells Plus[/i], this game's sequel, continues from there and I'd like to give it a try sometime.

[i]Hexcells[/i] was a nice game to play on my lunch break, although I do wish it did have a slightly steeper difficulty curve.
