10634046.review:
I got Hexcells Plus as part of a bundle, and after playing the first few levels I immediately purchased Hexcells so that I could play them in order. I didn't expect to enjoy these games as much as I did. The games are a mix of Minesweeper and Sodoku, plus a few extra twists.

This game ran very well on my netbook at 1024x600 resolution (CPU: 1GHz dual-core AMD C-50), so I think that virtually any computer will be able to hande this game. If you are contemplating buying this game then you might as well get the Hexcells Bundle with both games (especially if you are proficient at logic puzzles). The difficulty curve in the second game starts exactly where the first game ended.

All the levels can be completed without having to resort to guessing, although sometimes you wont believe this. But even when you are unable to determine (for example) which two cells contain the mine, knowing that it is either one or the other may give you enough of a clue to clear a third cell. It is very satisfying when you eventually figure out the puzzle.

The only real con that I found to this game was that despite the harder levels taking some time to complete, there is a great sense of wanting to play just one more level when you do manage to finish it. This can be lead to some very late nights!

Finally, a tip. If you are used to playing Minesweeper, you might like to swap the left & right mouse button actions in the configuration screen so that the right mouse button flags a cell as a blue cell (or a mine in Minesweeper parlance). I kept making mistakes all the time until I did this.

10456836.review:
Highly recommend this game. The levels are designed in such a way that you never have to guess; what makes it better is that there are usually multiple avenues towards solving each given level. If you're finding it too difficult to solve one area of (solvable, but tricky) hexes, it's often the case that you can make progress in a separate area before returning with a little more information. 

I would have liked to see some more content, but it was cool how the game kept with the hexagon theme. 6 worlds with 6 levels each. (Though admittedly, a few of the levels were filler / instructional, and didn't pose as much of a challenge.) I wonder if an optional timed mode would be a good idea. On the one hand, it would be nice to come back to the levels in a few months and see how fast I solve them second time around, but on the other hand, the pressure might take away from the uncluttered minimalist feel of the game. 

Overall, thorougly enjoyed Hexcells & Hexcells Plus and would definitely recommend as a stimulating challenge.

10425093.review:
Logic Puzzles.  

Pros
The idea is fantastic.  The game is easy to learn, In fact, it's a LOT like minesweeper without actually being minesweeper.  It's much better in my opinion.  The graphics are minimalist, which emphasize the clean logic of the game.  The music is calm and relaxing.

Cons
It's short.  I finished all the puzzles in 2.5 hours.
The logic only goes so far.  For a casual gamer this is probably a plus.  You don't have to derive clues from more than 2 orders.  But a few of the later puzzles will make you do a lot of 2nd order deductions.
But just when it was getting really, really good..it ended *pouty face*
Not much for replay value.  You can play the puzzles again.  But you should probably let the game accumulate some dust and come back to it in a year, then it will probably be fun all over again.

Summary
It's fun. I really like it, but it's just so short!

10421595.review:
- Hexcells kısaca (hepimizin kurallarını bilmese de ismini bildiği) "Mayın Tarlası" oyununun oldukça üst düzey hali. Eğer mayın tarlasının başında saatler harcamaktan hoşlanan biriyseniz kesinlikle oynamanız gereken bir oyun. Hexcells, klasik "sağında-solunda şu kadar mayın var" mantığı ile başlayıp satır-sütün-çapraz şu kadar mayın var, bunlar ardarda, bunlar ayrı gibi çok değişik stillerle oynanışı daha zor ama daha eğlenceli hâle getirilen bir bulmaca oyunu.

- Oyunun olumlu yönlerinden bahsedersem öncelikle müzikleri harika. Oyunun havasına uygun sakinleştirici ve dinlendiren ezgiler bulmacalarda size eşlik ediyor. Bulmaca çeşitliliği de yeterli düzeyde; ilk oyunda 30, ikinci oyunda ise 36 ayrı bulmaca var. (Gönül isterdi daha çok olsun ama yapacak birşey yok.)
- Oyunun eksik kalan yanları ise bulmacayı yarıda bırakıp çıkamıyorsunuz, eğer çıkarsanız o bulmacada bulduğunuz herşey gidiyor. İkinci bir eksik ise bulmacalar rastgele değil, bu yüzden yeniden oynanabilirlik azalıyor. (Tabi çözümü daha sonra hatırladığınızı varsayıyorum.) Benim için eksik olmasa da bazı arkadaşlar üçüncü olarak ipucu isteme gibi bir imkanın olmadığından yakınabilirler.

- Oyunu alacak iseniz Hexcell Bundle almanızı tavsiye ederim çünkü orta düzey mayın tarlası oyuncusu iseniz "Hexcells" oldukça kolay gelecektir.  "Hexcells Plus" ise adından da anlaşılacağı gibi normal modun üst seviyesi. Plus'ta gerçekten oldukça güzel hazırlanmış, tahmin yürüterek değil de emin olarak ilerlemenin zor olduğu, saatlerinizi çok rahat tüketen bulmacalar var. Hatta ilk oyun, Plus versiyonun yanında ısınma turu gibi kalıyor. 

- Sonuç olarak türü seven biriyseniz bundle olarak alınca $5 eden bu iki oyun, parasını sonuna kadar hak ediyor diyebilirim. Kesinlikle tavsiye ediyorum..

Minesweeper !!! Le démineur revu et corrigé [u][b]voire raffiné et sophistiqué[/b][/u]. 

Le mécanisme : découvrir des cases hexagonales, les bonnes, de couleur bleue, sont cernées de cases informatives indiquant avec combien d'autres hexagones bleutés, la case considérée est en contact. A vous de déduire si un hexagone est un bleu ou une info. Un click gauche si pensez que c'est un bleu, un click droit pour l'autre alternative. Chaque erreur est ensuite comptabilisée. Baissez votre quantité d'erreurs totale pour déverrouiller les niveaux supérieurs. 
[u][b]Il a également une propension très agréable à la symétrie/asymétrie [/b][/u]

Soyons bref, c'est un prélude très simple à Hexcells Plus, apparemment. C'est amusant et curieusement la rejouabilité est bien là. 
Mais même s'il bénéficie d'une certaine rejouabilité, il n'en demeure pas moins trop court pour son prix de vente régulier. 
Cependant, il vous surprendra en ajoutant efficacement plusieurs contraintes/mécaniques de jeu au fil de l'expérience. Addictif et agréable : j'approuve !

10415245.review:
Encore une fois j'ai craqué.

Hexcells est - encore une fois - un puzzle game minimaliste sauce Cipher Prime ou presque (je veux dire, sonnez les trompettes, tout ça : pour une fois y'a un bouton "QUIT").
Le jeu est simple, sympathique, bien qu'un peu court.
Le gameplay, euh... Voyez le démineur ? Bah pareil, version hexagones, et avec une touche en plus. 
Clic gauche pour colorer les cases à garder, clic droit pour supprimer celles qui ne le sont pas. Vraiment. Démineur, quoi.
Par contre, contrairement à son ancêtre, il peut être indiqué sur les colonnes/rangées/diagonales ou sur les cases même le nombre de cases à colorer, et ce de 3 manières. D'abord un indice global, par exemple "3". Ensuite, deux indices plus spécifiques : "{3}", qui indique que les trois cases à garder se suivent autour de notre hexagone ou le long de la rangée/colonne/whatever. Enfin, "-3-" indique que les trois ne se suivent pas. Autrement dit, cet indice équivaut à "1-1-1 ou 1-2 ou 2-1".
Mais passons ces banalités. Le jeu en vaut-il la chandelle ? Moui. Mnon. Tout dépend de ce que vous en attendez et de votre niveau de nerditude déminesque. Si vous êtes champion toutes catégories du passe-temps préféré du bureaucrate des années '90, vous en aurez pour 1 heure, un peu plus peut-être. Si vous êtes un joueur moyen, comptez ma foi deux bonnes heures. C'est court. Mais d'un autre côté le jeu est aussi vendu en bundle avec son équivalent plus corsé, Hexcells Plus. Et là le deal vaut selon moi le coup.

Ceci dit, est-ce que le jeu est plaisant ?
Oui, tout à fait. Un démineur à look léché avec ambiance sonore tranquille et bien foutue, difficile de faire plus avec si peu.

Et difficile d'en dire plus, aussi. On va résumer : 
Toi aimer démineur, toi acheter en bundle. Toi aimer puzzle games minimalistes, toi acheter en bundle. 
Toi pas aimer jeux comme ça, quoi toi foutre sur page de reviews de jeu de ce genre ? O_o

10415162.review:
Das Spiel an und für sich ist eigentlich sehr schön und liebevoll gemacht. Was mich jedoch im Endeffekt aufgeregt hat, ist, dass man so ziemlich dasselbe Spiel kostenlos normalerweise schon am Rechner hat: Minesweeper. Gegen Ende ist es dann ein wenig komplexer, was aber nicht unbedingt positiv ist, denn durch die ganzen verschiedenen Angaben wird es eher zu einem Konzentrationsspiel als einem Denkspiel. Da ich das Prinzip von Minesweeper  gut kenne, hab ich die Rätsel seehr schnell durchgespielt und ohne Pause dazwischen. Wie man an meiner Spielzeit sehen kann, dauerte es nicht lange.
Dadurch, dass ich noch Guthaben am Konto hatte, habe ich wenige Cent dafür ausgegeben und dafür ist die Enttäuschung dann doch nicht so groß. Für jemanden, der Minesweeper nicht kennt, beziehungsweise nicht so liebevoll findet, ist es dann vielleicht doch das Richtige. Jedoch hat man bei einem richtigen Logik-Rätselheft eindeutig mehr abwechslung und sitzt länger daran.

Two things I'd like to see. 
First: please make it easy to figure out which levels have perfect score, and which ones don't... I'm at 99% done and it bugs me!
Second: please put Level 5-4 inside the level, instead of Level 24 for example. It would be so much easier to keep track of where I'm at like that.

Overall Rating 4/5

I got this when it was out on Desura, and I thoroughly enjoyed it then. It's a very mellow, zen game which is easy to pick up, and the rules of play are introduced slowly enough that you're not overwhelmed by them. Each puzzle has a completely logical progression all the way to the finish (unlike Minesweeper, which it's similar to in terms of basic gameplay).

Only real complaint is that there aren't more puzzles, or a random puzzle generator to give it some more replayability. For those that want more, there's Hexcells Plus with some new puzzles, and Hexcells Infinite as well.

10017759.review:
强化版的扫雷，对，就是那个Win自带的神作扫雷……核心机制一模一样，黄格是未探索，黑格是安全，蓝格是雷，在黑格中会标示相邻格子中雷的数量，当然为了和经典扫雷做出区分，在系统上有着不少变化

看截图就知道这个是六角格版的扫雷，这一变化除了让画面更加美观以外，还给人带来了不少新鲜感，其实在系统上这种变化本身反而降低了了扫雷的难度，因为每一格只有六个邻格，而不是传统的八个，为了弥补难度上的缺失作者加了更多因素进去，同时也让这款游戏更加独特

过几关后会加入部分单列的总雷数标示，数字所标示的单列总雷数已知（因为是六角格所以“列”是可以有三个方向的），可以纳入作为计算要素，注意通常这不作为附加信息而是必要信息，没这些提示根本无法推理出雷的位置；
再过几关会加入标示-X-和{X}（X为周围雷数）的黑格，前者表示邻格的雷并不全部相连，后者表示邻格的雷全部相连，同样作为判断雷位置的必要信息；
再过几关会加入-X-和{X}状的单列总雷数标示，同样前者表该列的雷并不全部相连，后者表示该列的雷全部相连，同样作为必要信息

添加这些要素以后算法就变得相对复杂，作者为了确保额外信息都是“必要的”，放弃了随机生成关卡，而是全使用内置关卡，所以会出现各种奇怪的不规则的图形（不像传统扫雷，永远都是一个矩形），这样做一方面让游戏更加美观和独特，另一方面也保证了玩家不需要猜单靠推理就能过关（不知道下一步怎么走一定是玩家自己疏漏了某些信息）。不过内置关卡也意味着大家可以靠连续猜来过关，大不了猜错重开关卡（为了全成就，每关最多只允许错误一次），每次雷的位置都是固定的，而且没有随机关卡也意味着游戏寿命有限，一共就36关，打完以后我不知道还有什么理由再继续玩这个游戏，也许Hexcells对不怎么玩扫雷的人来说是个不小的挑战，但像我这样过去经常刷Win版扫雷记录的熟手，2小时就能收完成就过关了

----------------醒目的分割线----------------
如果你和我一样善于扫雷，那么你需要去玩Hexcells Plus！
这是另一个游戏，作者竟然拆成两部来卖，不过我还是一起评测了好了

Hexcells Plus的难度骤升，在基础版上引入了?黑格，点开以后等于没提供任何信息，让作者可以更大程度上控制关卡，经常某关如果不用猜的话只有通过固定顺序的信息整合推理才能顺利过关，加上一关比一关大，光信息控制这点就够大家受的了；
?黑格之外，Plus同时引入了标有数字的蓝格，数字表示周围两圈（共18格）内的总雷数，计算素材又增加了（某关甚至全部黑格都是?，需要靠蓝格里的数字配合单列雷数标示来过关）

一般过Plus会需要8-10小时，而且某些关卡会难到逼我用猜来判断雷的位置（也许大家仔细整合线索慢慢进行推理可以全程无猜），这才是强化版扫雷游戏应有的难度啊，耗时也对得起它的价格，欢迎各位前去挑战

补充：Hexcells原版和Plus都用左键标雷，右键踩地，和Win版扫雷是相反的，开始害我老按错……另外注意标错雷也算一次失误，不过和经典扫雷不同允许多次失误，不要成就的话多猜几次总是能过去

9887097.review:
[h1]A Change in Opinion[/h1]
This is an edit, and below I have preserved my original review because most of what I say is still valid. Since I wrote the original review, I have ended up purchasing Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite, and in light of those two sequels, I decided I really ought to change my recommendation of the original game from not recommended to recommended. It may be too easy, but it's a great introduction to the concept and more than worth getting if you go for the Hexcells bundle.

The following is my original review:

[h1]At the Time of Writing[/h1]
[b]Game:[/b] Hexcells
[b]Price:[/b] $3.29*
[b]Genre:[/b] Puzzle
[b]Time Played:[/b] <2 hours
[b]Personal Enjoyment Rating:[/b] ☺☺☺☻☻(out of 5)

[h1]General[/h1]
Although on the whole, I really enjoyed this game, there really isn't enough of it, and certainly not for $3 when it only amused me for a little under 2 hours. I am a logic puzzle fan, and I found the puzzles to be too few and too simple. They were only just barely starting to get interesting when the game ended. 

At the time of writing this review, the steam achievements are somewhat broken. Closing the game and opening it again will trigger the achievements. However this meant that during my one game session, I was lulled into a false sense of security that I was only in world 1 because no achievement for unlocking world 2 had popped up. This made the end of the game very abrupt because I thought there were going to be another 5 worlds yet!

Now, I know that there is an expansion to this called [i]Hexcells Plus[/i]. Despite how much I enjoy the concept, I feel that charging another $3 for those extra puzzles is a bit rich. I didn't enjoy the first game enough to warrant purchasing the next pack when I can buy an entire book of Japanese logic puzzles for about the same (which takes a lot longer to complete, are harder, and don't require a computer to do).

In all fairness, if you wanted to give this a shot, it was very very enjoyable whilst it lasted. Although the tutorial levels seemed to take up half of the entire game, they were paced almost perfectly. So whilst I might ultimately (and regretfully) be giving this a thumbs down, my reason for doing so is not due to the concept or the quality of the game, but rather the lack of quantity and difficulty considering the pricing. Perhaps this would be an excellent game for someone who is new to logic puzzles, or for amusing a brainy child.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The concept of the game is very interesting and has great potential. I feel it is best described as a cross between Minesweeper and Hanjie**. Whilst there are cells that you can think of as being "mines" making a mistake doesn't mean you instantly lose the level, it just counts as a mistake. In addition, depending on how the numbers are presented, some "mines" are consecutive, and others must not be consecutive.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
A simple mouse game, left click and right click are used. I found the designations counter-intuitive and made many silly mistakes because I clicked the wrong button. After finishing the game, and reopening it I discovered that you can rebind the two actions (mark a cell & uncover a cell) in the configuration screen that pops up before the game itself opens. However, this was really too late and it makes no sense why such a basic option is not accessible inside of the game in a prominent location (even if it were as simple as switching what the mouse buttons do).

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
No storyline, doesn't need one.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Relaxing gentle zen echoie noises. Also, when you click a cell you get nice tinkling chime-like noises. I don't know why that makes it more satisfying to click on cells, but it does!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Very crisp, clean, and clear. The numbers are reasonably large. Some puzzles form an interesting overall image or pattern, but that really isn't a necessity in my opinion. I'd rather have some hard puzzles. But overall, the puzzles come across as well designed.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]+ [/b]crisp clean graphics whose job is to be functional
[b]+ [/b]simple controls to grasp
[b]+ [/b]more interesting concept than random old Minesweeper
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]- [/b]expensive for what it is
[b]- [/b]not enough puzzles
[b]- [/b]puzzles are too simple/easy
[b]- [/b]switching the mouse button actions is hidden outside the game

[h1]Help Me Help You[/h1]
[b]If you did not find this review helpful,[/b] I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

[h1]Rothana's Steam Review Archive[/h1]
For those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: [b]rothana dot weebly dot com[/b]

[b]Footnotes[/b]
*The prices I give are in CDN because that's what I see. This is also the full price.
**Hanjie is a Japanese logic puzzle. According to some random site called Goobix, Hanjie is also known by the following names: "[Nonograms], Paint by numbers, Crucipixel, Edel, FigurePic, Grafilogika, Griddlers, Hanjie, Illust-Logic, Japanese Crosswords, Japanese Puzzles, Kare Karala!, Logic Art, Logic Square, Logicolor, Logik-Puzzles, Logimage, Oekaki-Mate, Paint Logic, Pic-a-Pix, Picross, Pixel Puzzles, Shchor Uftor and Tsunami."

27/11/2014 improved the formatting of the review

9814010.review:
A modern classic of a puzzle game let down only by short length, and lack of a level generator or level editor/workshop support. A fantastic advertisement for Hexcells Plus, and Matthew Brown's games in general.

When this started, I was thinking (as apparently everyone else does) "updated Minesweeper, with better music and graphics."

As more gameplay mechanics were introduced, I stopped thinking about minesweeper - this is something mch, much more intelligent and much, much more involving. It's still a game where you're deducing the position of tiles that should be left-clicked and ones that should be right-clicked, but the ways you determine which are which change as the game progresses, allowing for some intricate and elegant puzzle solving.

The new gameplay elements represent both a challenge and a tool, meaning the game feels incredibly well-balanced - you're unlikely to ever throw your hands up because something became too complicated. Rules are added as if the entire game were a complete tutorial, to the point that in the later stages, you notice the position of something at a different angle to before, and you instantly understand what this means.

All new rules are introduced with a mini-tutorial puzzle so you get the chance to try them out on the small stage before moving on to a larger-scale puzzle. You can restart and replay levels, which is great if you're like me and have the kind of fingers that left-click when you wanted them to right-click. I think I had one level where I made the same one mistake 5 times, just through being cackhanded... and it's not like I've never played any Portal game, so the blame is squarely at my feet for any frustration I experienced there. That's a nice thing about this puzzle game - it's very friendly, very calming. I complained only at myself (for having stupid fingers, or for making a dumb move), never, ever at the game.

The game looks beautiful - cool colors, minimalist layout - my only gripe is that the menu text looked a bit washed out on my screen - it took a while to be able to see the 'Quit' text - for example - and the music is excellent, accompanied by ambient chimes that play in tune with the music - if you wanted to you could turn the solving of a level into a pretty pleasing musical performance with a little practice.

Achievements are slightly bugged, in that you'll only get them (or at least I only did) the next time you start the game and continue your last save slot. And that's where the game has its biggest letdown - as I understand it, it only has 6 worlds. Not getting the achievements the first time through, made me think that perhaps each world was made up of 6 sets of puzzles, and that the numbers on the homescreen represented the first 3 worlds. Not so. I've unlocked the final world just now, and my game is registering around 2.2 hours played - and that includes leaving the game running for at least half an hour while I did something else.

There's probably 2 hours of gameplay for most people in this, which you may feel is not enough to justify whatever price is being charged. I got this via the Bundlestars Indie Capsule 2, so at most it was around $5 (if I ignored all the other games in that bundle), and I feel that was definitely worth the price. 

To sum up - Hexcells is a game that seems at once familiar and modern, is challenging without being frustrating, looks good, sounds good, is good value for money, and is a satisfying gameplay experience that leaves you wanting more of the same. 

Get it. It is good.

9634829.review:
[b][h1]Campo minado com hexágonos[/h1][/b]
Hexcells é um game indie desenvolvido e publicado pela Matthew Brown Games, lançado em fevereiro de 2014 para PC.

Essencialmente Hexcells é um puzzles que se assemelha em muito com o clássico Campo Minado, mas ao invés de se encontrar as minas no mapa, o jogador deve encontrar o hexágonos azuis, com a mesma mecânica de indicar a posição dos hexágonos através de números que revelam a quantidade de hexágonos ao redor do mesmo.


Mas assim como campo minado, Hexcells é um game extremamente casual, que se torna desafiador nas ultimas fases, mas que não oferece nada mais do que algumas horas de entretenimento. Um game que diverte aqueles que gostam de puzzles, mas que não chega a se tornar essencial para o gênero.

Um game para se jogar nos momentos vagos e exercitar o raciocínio.

[b]Informações adicionais:[/b]
Tempo de jogo: Dedicado aproximadamente 5 horas.
Conquistas desbloqueadas: 6 de 6.
Dificuldade: Mediana, aumentando conforme se libera novas faces.
Modo de jogo: Singleplayer.
Idioma: Inglês.

[b]Análise publicada originalmente no [url=http://portohq.blogspot.com.br/]Blog PortoHQ.[/url][/b]

9630344.review:
Not much to say, really. It's a minesweeper-ish puzzle, with more information so you never have to just guess. It's never complicated; if II'm not mistaken I rarely had to mentally play through a combination of two close hints to see where the possible solutions intersect to reveal a hex that has the same state in all possible solutions -- for most cases, it's just a simple going through the patterns.

Nonetheless, it's a decent little game. No replay value or anything like that since the levels are NOT randomly generated, and it's not going to take all that much time either, but it does what it sets out to do. If you can deal with just playing through this once in a rather short time, go for it. Avoid making guesses, you're just spoiling the experience for yourself.

A "recommendation" might be a bit too strong, but I can't really vote "No" for a game that does what it wants to do, and does it well enough. Consider it a weak recommendation.

好吧，当初玩扫雷我就玩了个通宵，这块加强版的扫雷对我来说自然也是非常有魅力的。而且逻辑比扫雷要严谨一些，基本上没有那种无从推理完全要靠蒙运气的状况（游戏过程中我只发现了一个）。可惜的是这个游戏没有卡牌掉落，而且每一关是固定的，不会变化，通关一次以后就没有什么可玩性了。

这个游戏只有6个成就，其中5个可以随着游戏的过程解锁，最后一个要求每一小关都完美达成（也就是不犯错），好在每一个小关都可以从菜单直接选，全成就非常容易。不过完成成就以后不会马上显示，要重启一下游戏才会激活，而且必须是全屏模式才行。

补充一句，这是唯一一个我全成就以后还不舍得删，时不时还会玩两把的游戏

9405454.review:
Bien qu'il rappelle des jeux de réflexion tels que Démineur ou encore Picross, Hexcells se distingue par sa structure hexagonale et ses règles évolutives.  Tout comme le Démineur, certaines cellules affichent des chiffres qui correspondent au nombre de cases bleues en contact avec cette dernière.  Au fur et à mesure que le jeu progresse, de nouvelles règles s'ajoutent et demandent davantage de réflexion, à l'instar de Picross.  Ainsi, la présence d'un chiffre au-dessus d'une colonne, entouré de parenthèses ou de tirets, signifiera que des cases bleues se touchent ou non.  La courbe de progression    du jeu, bien calculée, permet de bien assimiler ces nouvelles règles.  S'il est possible de compléter un niveau en ayant commis des erreurs, les complétionnistes voudront y retourner pour obtenir une note parfaite.  Fait à noter, les niveaux où des erreurs ont été commises sont légèrement plus sombres que les autres, ce qui n'est pas très clair.  La bande sonore est très apaisante et convient bien au style du jeu.  Toutes les énigmes peuvent être complétées en-dedans de 4 heures.

Points positifs

+ Jeu de réflexion stimulant et apaisant
+ Règles évolutives maintenant l'intérêt

Points négatifs

- Affichage des niveaux incomplets trop subtil

9400798.review:
I don't typically throw the term art around when refering to games, but this one deserves the title more over. The simplistic atmosphere and exceptional soundtracks creates a calm atmosphere while playing. The feeling the game creates helps to think when solving the tasks presented. This twist on the classic minesweeper takes a little getting used to at first, but quickly teachers you most of what you'll need to know.

Despite the legnth being a little shorter than desired, my only real complaint is the tutorial system. This worked fine until World 3, which after I had no idea how to play and found myself guessing far too often. If either the devs or an individual were to put out a bit more in-depth tutorial or guide on those final mechanics, the game would be much more enjoyable.

9394999.review: The love child of Minesweeper and Picross, Hexcells is spectacular.  If you like puzzle mapping games, give it a try.  You won't be disappointed.

9366348.review:
This is every review for this game says but imagine Minesweeper but FUN instead of frustrating. 
Between the Soundtrack, the clean minimalistic look, the more forgiving mechanics and the more interesting puzzles this really is the casual 5 minute brain-scratcher you'd fire up without a second thought.

Each puzzle is hand-made (for lack of a better word) and comes with a guarantee that you can solve it logically, start to finish, no guessing or blowing up when trying to uncover the field required (And seriously, don't ever guess, you're shooting yourself in the foot). 
The addition of adding column-information as well as the regular tiles, later in the game, adds loads of new possibilities and requires a new way of thinking, reminiscent of solving a Sudoku puzzle. 

The only downside of these puzzles is, that because they're hand-made, they're not infinitely generated, but instead treated as 29 levels in 6 "worlds" giving this limited replayability. 
Depending on how long each puzzle takes you, you'll get a couple of hours of gameplay out of this, maybe a few more if you want to go for perfect to correct mis-clicks and mistakes. You can replay the levels of course, but I'm not sure how long it'll take you before you can solve the puzzles by memory rather than by logic. 
Because of this, I'd recommend buying this with Hexcells Plus included, which will give you an additional 36 puzzles.

Caldamente consigliato.

9341079.review:
Articolo completo: http://theshelternetwork.com/hexcells/

Ai creatori di videogiochi piacciono gli esagoni: celle di sei lati le abbiamo viste in numerosi titoli, dal seminale Hex su Atari ST fino al più recente Civilization V, passando per numerosi strategici a turni e adattamenti da board game. Mattew Brown si inserisce nella lunga lista degli amanti di questa figura piana con Hexcells, un puzzle game dal titolo che più esplicativo non si può.
Abbiamo infatti a che fare con figure più o meno complesse composte da tante celle esagonali (denominate “Hex”), quasi come se fossero degli alveari: al giocatore il compito di “svelare” la struttura secondo un funzionamento che ricorda il mitico Campo Minato. Pardon, Fiorito.

Ci sono infatti tre tipi di celle: le celle “piene”, di color azzurro; le celle “vuote”, di color nero; e infine le celle “ignote”, di color arancione. Lo scopo è quello di “rivelare” la natura delle celle, marcando con un bel click sinistro le celle che si ritiene debbano assumere il colore del cielo in una bella giornata primaverile di sole e cliccando invece con il pulsante destro dei nostri mouse su quegli esagoni che si ipotizzi siano nere. Come intuire la vera natura delle caselle? Ma con i numeri all’interno delle celle vuote, ovvio: un bell’esagono con un 4 al centro vuol dire che quattro sono gli esagoni adiacenti che sono pieni – quindi da “azzurrare” – mentre i restanti due sono da distruggere con un click destro. Si procede così, di esagono in esagono, di numeretto in numeretto, in stage con figure sempre più articolate e con sempre più Hex.

Il giocatore un pelo smaliziato non incontrerà molte difficoltà: l’assenza di qualsivoglia limite temporale suggerisce presto un approccio lento, quasi da “Settimana Enigmistica”, dove l’importante è più aguzzare la vista e osservare bene lo schema che la rapidità di pensiero. La maggior parte degli errori deriva infatti dalla troppa spavalderia del giocatore: questo almeno fino al tredicesimo livello (di trenta). Presto infatti arriveranno altri elementi a scombussolare le carte: cifre al di fuori degli esagoni che indicano la quantità di celle blu presenti in quella riga/colonna/diagonale, numeri tra parentesi graffe ({3}) che urlano “Attento! Gli esagoni blu sono consecutivi” e altri tra segni meno (-2-) che sussurrano “Ohi, gli esagoni pieni non sono consecutivi”. Sembra quasi di essere degli scultori, come in Picross, che scoprono con il proseguire del gioco nuove tecniche per cesellare le proprie creazioni all’interno degli stage. E così negli ultimi livelli la difficoltà si impenna non poco, tanto che nemmeno la più calma delle tracce sonore potrà quietare la rabbia per il decimo errore consecutivo.

Il gioco poi risulta assolutamente affascinante se si considera il suo aspetto audiovisivo: la grafica è semplice, pulita, minimale – a volte fin troppo, con menu quasi invisibili – condita da un accompagnamento musicale d’eccellenza. Siamo dalle parti di soffuse ed eteree sonorità ambient, che si impreziosiscono di piccoli sprazzi di note a ogni azione – siano esse giuste che errori – del giocatore, trasformandolo in coautore della traccia audio. Roba che manderà in visibilio tutti gli amanti della musica più minimale e d’atmosfera, e che resta comunque gradevolissima a tutti gli altri. Discorso a parte merita invece il fattore longevità: è vero che Hexcells costa pochissimo (sui 3€ su Steam), ma è innegabile che l’esperienza è talmente breve che potrebbe risultare quasi più impalpabile del sottofondo musicale. Ho impiegato circa 110 minuti per giungere all’ultimo stage, considerato pure che sono ritornato su qualche livello per affinare alcune performance con troppi errori. Ecco perché su Steam il titolo è venduto anche in bundle con Hexcells Plus, espansione stand alone che aggiunge 36 nuovi e complessi livelli, al prezzo di circa 5€.

Insomma, se cercate un puzzle game dalle ottime meccaniche e dalla solida personalità, Hexcells è assolutamente consigliato.
Se cercate invece il nuovo Tetris che vi terrà incollati allo schermo per il resto della vostra vita, o se avete paura degli esagoni, dirigete la vostra attenzione verso altri rompicapo.

9301065.review:
I absolutely adore this game.  The basic idea is Picross/Nonograms + Minesweeper on a Hex grid.  If you like either of the forementioned games, please do yourself a favor and pick this up.  The learning curve is wonderfully laid out and it seems as though most of the game is slowly moving you towards the final few puzzles where it puts everything you've learned to work.  

The ambient music and minimalist design makes this game soothing to play, even when it is taxing on your mind.  The controls are simple and flawless, just using the left and right mouse click as in the classic Minesweeper game.  It is rare for an experience so simple to be this enjoyable.  I can't wait to play Hexcells Plus to see if they add either more to the already great puzzle system they have put into place, or if it is just more of the endgame style puzzles to be wonderfully entertained by.  Again, if you like Picross and Minesweeper, even things like Sudoku or other logic games, do yourself a favor and toss the few bucks it is asking.  You'll get a few hours of fun out of it and definitely not be disappointed.

9299444.review: Great fun puzzle game. If puzzles is your thing, this is the game for you.

This gets a 3 out of 3

9267833.review:

9265218.review:
It isn't all that bad. Think of it as the love child of picross and mine sweeper, except that child grew up to be a bit simple and shallow. So although it looked ok as a young adult and some some people kind of fancied it, ultimately it is a one night stand kind of person and not a real candidate for a long term relationship.

So you can have sex with this game for a couple of hours, but it is never going to be "good sex". You'd probably be best just firing one off in the bathroom to be honest. But if it is already in your house and you have nobody better to call on? Yeah why not, sure.

Just be careful because the mechanic of marking each cell is a little fiddly and you will frequently make silly mistakes. You will get used to it, but it is a bit of a distraction when a proven method for "flagging" a cell is available (rather than committing to it). It holds the game back a little, but otherwise it does the job.

9241149.review:
[u]"Ох, жизнь ты поле минное, и я на нем сапер!"[/u]
В полку клонов сапера прибыло! Знакомьтесь Hexcells! По сути игра отлчается от сапера тем что ошибаться здесь можно, клеточки здесь шестигранные, а мины синенькие.Присмотревшись еще сильне понимаешь что от сапера остались только основные правила ,остальное взяли из так называемых нонограмм ,иначе говоря "японских кроссвордов".И это сочетание пошло игре на пользу, она стала интереснее и сложнее обычного сапера. Но есть и существенные недостатки

Первый недостаток игры очень полярен,в прямом смысле, здесь можно ошибаться, для перфекциониста игра превращается в сущиий ад, совершил две ошибки и прощай Perfect. Но для обычного человека возможность ошибаться превращает игру в увелеселительную прогулку.Это и есть второй минус игры ,чтобы ее проити на Perfect потребуется часа 4.Но этот минус искупляется тем что к игре выпущен аддон Hexcells Plus, он сложнее оригинальной игры и требует больше времени и усидчивости я его так и не прошел. Из технических плюсов можно отметить то игра запускается на слабых машинах и машинах с ОС на ядре [strike] ЖМУ/ЛИНУПС[/strike] GNU/Linux.

9236448.review:
I'm loving this one.  Pure logic puzzles.  

To oversimplify, the game is like 6-sided Minesweeper without the random elements, with elements of Sudoku entering the later levels.  Every puzzle can be solved without guessing.  There's a clear difficulty progression through the levels.  Low stress too, since if you get one wrong, the board doesn't blow up - you just increment an error counter.

The ONLY thing wrong is the lack of a random level generator.  Once you beat the included levels, you're done.  But looking at the value (time/money), it's still a great deal.  (And the follow-on game, Hexcells Plus, is also cheap and just as excellent, with slightly higher difficulty.)

Very highly recommended.

9229505.review:

6/10

9224518.review:
Really nice, weird blend between Minesweeper and Sudoku-ish games. The first two "worlds" seem really simple and minesweeperish, but once they introduce rows, columns, and brackets, you find yourself thinking more like you would when playing Sudoku (re-checking rows, etc). 

If you like puzzle games, this is a solid couple of playsessions of puzzling. Hexcells Plus also seems like a winner; it seems to reward you for being good at the first game.

Il sonoro è eccellente e un puzzle tira l'altro, non sono complicati (a parte gl'ultimi) però garantiscono soddisfazione al completamento, peccato ci siano solamente 30 livelli, un po' pochini considerando che i primi sono puzzle semplicissimi che fungono da tutorial.
Che altro dire, costa 3 euro vale la pena dargli una possibilità.

Voto: 7/10

9220539.review:
Hexcells presents a spin on the classic Minesweeper formula, but Hexcells quickly surpasses the iconic Windows game. While Minesweeper offered little in the way of guideance, Hexcells is brilliantly designed. Sharing elements of Picross, each puzzle can be logically solved with zero blind guessing. The ambient tones are a treat, and the zen atmosphere the game manufactures is well done and marries well with the elegant visual polish. 

The experience is short. Most players can finish the game and complete all achievements in 2-3 hours. Those wishing for more can buy the Hexcells Plus expansion, and hopefully, we can look forward to more expansions down the road.

Make sure to play with headphones - the music and sound effects are lovely, very zen.

9213350.review:
Deceptively sleek and simple, yet beautifully intricate and complex. The apparent similarities to Minesweeper are rather superficial as Hexcells expands much farther into logical depth. This is one of the most charming and satisfying (PC) puzzle games I've played and it is especially well priced. 

The only real negative is that the game is way too short, and even combined with the more advanced "expansion" (Hexcells+), most players will quickly be hungry for more content. Fortunately, the puzzles retain an incredible amount of replayability despite not being randomly generated.

Overall highly recommended, even for those who don't typically play puzzle games.

Edit: Having replayed the game and having a bit more experience with it, I can safely say that while it can feel that a guess is the only way to complete a level, there is always a way to find the solution that doesn't revolve around guessing, so I now think even more highly of the game.

9196512.review: A most excellent, if short, puzzle game. It will occupy your mind pretty much completely for a couple of hours while you try to get the elusive 100%. 9190149.review:
Hexagonal Minesweeper! With some Picross / Nonogram mechanics thrown in for taste sometimes.

Was not expecting this to work out so well as an interesting puzzle game. Pleasantly surprised! Also, the visual and sound design are elegant and polished and very relaxing! 

And it's short, but it's cheap. And it's got an expansion set so it's not so short. Yep, no objections with this one! 

If "Cheap zen hexagonal minesweeper" sounds appealing to you, go for it. Achievement hunters looking to bag another easy 100% game for their collection, you should probably consider this one, too.

9189870.review:
A simple puzzle/logic game that you will probably finish in a couple of hours. The music is soothing and the gameplay probably couldn't be any simpler without it being boring. It chucks in a new mechanic every world (there are six) to make the gameplay possibly seem easier or harder.

For 3 bucks, there is no reason why you shouldn't have this game.

9189858.review:
Hexcells is a great puzzle game. While the game borrows elements from picross and Minesweeper, I find Hexcells to be an improvement on both. Unlike Minesweeper, every puzzle is completely solvable based on the available clues - no frustrating leaps of faith required. The game becomes more rewarding with each new puzzle as new strategies are needed and solutions go from obvious to head-scratchers. The final sets require a variety of styles of deductive reasoning to solve the cleverly designed puzzles without errors.

The puzzles themselves are fantastic and engaging, but the ambiance is what should make this a must-buy for fans of any genre. Each click helps weave together a living soundtrack that connects you with each puzzle. The aesthetics put you into the perfect "flow" mentality and add immensely to the overall experience. If you're a puzzle fan, don't hesitate to pick this up, and don't be surprised when you return to send a few copies to your friends and family.

9188729.review: A small game, but once I started, I sat here for two hours until I finished it.  I guess you could say Hexcells' grandfather is Minesweeper, but toss a layer of basic math over it, and you've got a puzzle that is more logical than 'click on the corner and hope there's no bomb', and also makes you feel clever by making you think a bit, but not so much your brain hurts.  I heartily recommend this game to anyone who likes casual puzzle games, because that's what it is, and a fine one at that.

9185248.review:
I adore Hexcells. In all honesty, the game isn't that difficult. There are a few tricky spots, but mostly the puzzles are rather easy. For me it's about 90 minutes of gameplay to totally max it out and get a perfect on every level.

But it's 90 minutes I enjoyed. The puzzle mechanics are fun, the music is lovely, the graphics are great. It all comes together very nicely.

Cheaper than a movie ticket, and good replay value -- the puzzles are still fun to go back and do again. (This is actually my second playthrough, as I completed the game once before prior to its Steam release.) If you ever enjoyed Minesweeper, give this a go.

I do hope there's a second puzzle pack released at some point, I'd love to play some more new levels!

EDIT: Apparently, there is also a Hexcells Plus which has different content in it. It is a much harder version of the game, so I'd still like a second puzzle pack with more regular Hexcells puzzles!

9181563.review:
This is probably the best puzzle game I have ever played.  The music and sound effects are spot-on fantastic, the puzzles are lovingly and painstakingly crafted, and the difficulty progression is just perfect from one puzzle to the next.

The mechanics are similar to Minesweeper and if you find yourself clicking the wrong mouse button (like me), you can change the button configuration from the Input tab of the configuration menu when you first start the game.

I have now bought this game twice at full price (I bought again when released on Steam) and I don't regret it in the slightest.  This game is worth well more than the $3 asking price.
